revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} '''Sir George Adrian Hayhurst Cadbury''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|CH|DL}} (15 April 1929 – 3 September 2015) was a British Olympic [[rowing (sport)|rower]] and Chairman of [[Cadbury plc|Cadbury and Cadbury Schweppes]] for 24 years. He was a pioneer in raising the awareness and stimulating the debate on [[corporate governance]] and produced the [[Cadbury Report]], a code of best practice which served as a basis for reform of corporate governance around the world.<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/adrian-cadbury-a-leader-in-corporate-governance-dies-at-86/2015/09/04/e87dd2fe-532e-11e5-8c19-0b6825aa4a3a_story.html</ref>
==Early life, education and rowing== Cadbury was born 15 April 1929,<ref name=Birth>{{cite web|title=Birthday's today|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/archive/2011-4-15.html |publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=14 April 2014|date=15 April 2011|quote=Sir Adrian Cadbury, Chairman, Cadbury Schweppes, 1975–89, 82}}</ref> a member of the Cadbury family who are known for their [[Quaker]] philosophy and the chocolate conglomerate which they founded. He was educated at [[Eton College|Eton]] and [[King's College, Cambridge]]. At Cambridge, he rowed in the losing [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] boat in the 1952 [[Boat Race]]. He also rowed in the Great Britain [[coxless four]] in the [[1952 Summer Olympics]] in Helsinki.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ca/adrian-cadbury-1.html |title=Adrian Cadbury Biography and Olympic Results |publisher=Sports Reference LLC |accessdate=3 July 2012}}</ref>
==Life in business== He joined the Cadbury business in 1958 and became Chairman of Cadbury Ltd in 1965. He retired as Chairman of Cadbury Schweppes in 1989. He was a Director of the [[Bank of England]] from 1970–94 and of [[IBM]] from 1975–94. He was Chairman of the UK Committee on the Financial Aspects of Corporate Governance which published its Report and Code of Best Practice ("[[Cadbury Report]] and Code") in December 1992. He was member of the [[OECD]] Business Sector Advisory Group on Corporate Governance. His publications include: ''Ethical Managers Make Their Own Rules''; ''The Company chairman''; ''Corporate Governance and Chairmanship: A Personal View''. He was appointed [[High Sheriff of the West Midlands]] for 1994–95.<ref>{{London Gazette| issue=53618|page=4244|date= 18 March 1994}}</ref>
==Support of Aston University== Sir Adrian had a long-standing relationship with [[Aston University]]. He served as Aston Chancellor between 1979 and 2004, later chaired the University's Development Board, and was one of the University's most generous supporters. As Chancellor Emeritus, Sir Adrian contributed to undergraduate and postgraduate courses, speaking in particular on governance, business ethics and corporate social responsibility.<ref>http://www.aston.ac.uk/about/news/releases/2015/january/sir-adrian-cadbury-in-new-year-honours-list/</ref> He was also a patron of Aston Raise and Give Society, which is the fundraising body of [[Aston University]]. As part of the 60th anniversary celebrations of [[Aston Business School]] in 2008, Sir Adrian was awarded a rare [[Beta Gamma Sigma]] Business Achievement Award. [[Aston Business School]]'s MBA lecture theatres were also named after Sir Adrian and Lady Susan Cadbury, in recognition of their long association with [[Aston University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://astonalumni.org/netcommunity/page.aspx?pid%3D881 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201155609/http://astonalumni.org/netcommunity/page.aspx?pid=881 |archivedate=1 February 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Honours and awards== He was made a [[Knight Bachelor]] in 1977, thereafter becoming Sir Adrian Cadbury. He was given the [[Freedom of the City]] of [[Birmingham]] in 1982. He was appointed as a [[Deputy Lieutenant]] (DL) of the [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]] in 1995.<ref>http://www.wmlieutenancy.org/deputy%20lieutenants%20on%20supplemental%20list.html#Cadbury {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150915015258/http://www.wmlieutenancy.org/deputy%20lieutenants%20on%20supplemental%20list.html |date=15 September 2015 }}</ref>
In recognition of his contribution to commerce, corporate governance and public life, Sir Adrian has received honorary degrees from many universities (including [[Aston University]], [[University of Birmingham]], [[Birmingham City University]], [[University of Cambridge]], and [[University of Bristol]]). In 1995 the Royal Society of Arts awarded Sir Adrian its [[Albert Medal (Royal Society of Arts)|Albert Medal]] and in 2001 he received one of the International Corporate Governance Network's inaugural awards. In early 2008, Sir Adrian was made an Honorary Fellow of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales (ICAEW).<ref>http://alumni-web-01.aston.ac.uk/alist/details/4/adrian-cadbury</ref>
Cadbury was a Steward of [[Henley Royal Regatta]] and the President of [[Birmingham Rowing Club]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.birminghamrowingclub.co.uk/?page_id=7 |title=Club Admin |author=Christopher Anton |date=15 September 2011 |publisher=Birmingham Rowing Club |accessdate=3 July 2012}}</ref>
Cadbury was appointed [[Member of the Order of the Companions of Honour]] (CH) in the 2015 New Year Honours for services to business and the community, especially in Birmingham.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=61092|supp=y|page=N28|date=31 December 2014}}</ref><ref>[https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/391413/New_Year_Honours_List_2015.pdf 2015 New Year Honours List] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102104907/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/391413/New_Year_Honours_List_2015.pdf |date=2 January 2015 }}</ref>
==Death== He died on 3 September 2015, aged 86.<ref name=Death>{{cite web|title=Adrian Cadbury, British corporate governance leader, dies at 86|url= http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-wp-blm-news-bc-cadbury-obit04-20150904-story.html |work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=4 September 2015|date=4 September 2015}}</ref>
==Publications== *Cadbury, A. (1992) ''Report and Code of Best Practice'' ([[Cadbury Report]] and Code), The Committee on the Financial Aspects of Corporate Governance, London: Gee and Company *Cadbury, Adrian (1995) ''The Company chairman (2nd Ed)'', NJ: Prentice Hall, {{ISBN|0-13-434150-3}} *Cadbury, Adrian (2002) ''Corporate Governance and Chairmanship: A Personal View'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|0-19-925200-9}}
==See also== *[[Cadbury]] *[[Corporate Governance]] *[[List of Cambridge University Boat Race crews]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150704084611/http://www.debretts.com/people-of-today/profile/17583/%28George%29-Adrian-Hayhurst-CADBURY ''Debrett's People of Today'']
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
[[File:1931.01.31 23 Andrussow Pilot Plant Herne Germany.jpg|thumb|right|Late 1930: Semitechnical plant for experiments on the production of hydrogen cyanide with the Andrussow process in [[Herne, Germany]], operated by [[Leonid Andrussow]].]] [[File:1931.01.31 23 Andrussow Pilot Plant diagramm Herne Germany.jpg|thumb|right|Diagram from 1931 showing the Andrussow process]] The '''Andrussow process''' is an industrial process for the production of [[hydrogen cyanide]] from [[methane]] and [[ammonia]] in the presence of [[oxygen]] and a [[platinum]] [[catalyst]].<ref>{{cite journal | title = Über die schnell verlaufenden katalytischen Prozesse in strömenden Gasen und die Ammoniak-Oxydation (V) | author = [[Leonid Andrussow]] | journal = Berichte der deutschen chemischen Gesellschaft | volume = 60 | issue = 8 | pages = 2005–2018 | year = 1927 | url = | doi = 10.1002/cber.19270600857 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title = Über die katalytische Oxydation von Ammoniak-Methan-Gemischen zu Blausäure (The catalytic oxidation of ammonia-methane-mixtures to hydrogen cyanide) | author = L. Andrussow | journal = [[Angewandte Chemie]] | volume = 48 | issue = 37 | pages = 593–595 | year = 1935 | url = | doi = 10.1002/ange.19350483702 }}</ref>
:CH<sub>4</sub> + NH<sub>3</sub> + 1.5 O<sub>2</sub> → HCN + 3 H<sub>2</sub>O
The process is based on a reaction that was discovered by [[Leonid Andrussow]] in 1927. In the following years he developed the process that is named after him. HCN is also produced in the [[BMA process]].
==Side reactions== This reaction is very [[exothermic reaction|exothermic]]. The change of [[Standard enthalpy of formation|enthalpy]] of this reaction is equal to ''-481.06 kJ''.<ref>{{Citation | first=Gyula | last=Deák | title=Menné reakcie v organickej chémii|year = 1980|publisher=Vydavateľstvo technickej a ekonomickej literatúry| location = Bratislava| page = 14|isbn=}}</ref> The [[heat]] provided by the main reaction serves as a catalyst for other side reactions. :CH<sub>4</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O → CO + 3 H<sub>2</sub> :2 CH<sub>4</sub> + 3 O<sub>2</sub> → 2 CO + 4 H<sub>2</sub>O :4 NH<sub>3</sub> + 3 O<sub>2</sub> → 2 N<sub>2</sub> + 6 H<sub>2</sub>O
These side reactions can be reduced by only short exposures to the catalyst of the order of 0.0003s.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Pirie|first=J M|title=The Manufacture of Hydrocyanic Acid by the Andrussow Process|journal=Platinum Metals Rev.|year=1958|volume=2|issue=1|pages=7–11|url=http://www.platinummetalsreview.com/pdf/pmr-v2-i1-007-011.pdf|accessdate=28 March 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Andrussow Oxidation}} [[Category:Organic redox reactions]] [[Category:Industrial processes]] [[Category:Catalysis]] [[Category:Name reactions]]

[[Image:MARC combination baggage car at Camden Station, October 2005.jpg|thumbnail|B&O Warehouse, east side]] [[Image:Oriole Park Baltimore.jpg|thumb|West side, from Oriole Park]] The '''B&O Warehouse''' is a building in [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]], adjacent to [[Oriole Park at Camden Yards]]. It was constructed by the [[Baltimore and Ohio Railroad]] (B&O) beginning in 1899, with later sections completed in 1905, adjacent to the B&O's [[Camden Yards station|Camden Station]] and freight yard at Camden and Eutaw streets. Often purported to be the longest brick building on the East Coast, the {{convert|1116|ft|m|0|adj=on}} long, eight-story brick structure had 430,000 square feet (almost 40,000 m²) of floor space for merchandise storage and distribution, large enough to hold 1,000 carloads of freight at a time, the B&O advertised.<ref>[[Herbert H. Harwood, Jr.]], ''Impossible Challenge''. Baltimore, Md.: Bernard, Roberts and Co., 1979 ({{ISBN|0-934118-17-5}}), p. 150.</ref> Railroad historian Herbert H. Harwood proclaimed it an "awesome structure ... a truly classic turn-of-the-century railroad warehouse."<ref>Harwood, p. 416.</ref> The warehouse was used by the B&O through the 1960s but was mostly vacant by the 1970s due to the use of trucks and newer, more efficient single-floor warehouses located in industrial parks elsewhere.<ref>Stephen J. Salamon, David P. Oroszi, and David P. Ori, ''Baltimore and Ohio – Reflections of the Capitol Dome''. Silver Spring, Md.: Old Line Graphics, 1993 ({{ISBN|1-879314-08-8}}), pp. 26–29.</ref>
With the development of the downtown stadium for the Orioles, which opened in 1992, the former B&O warehouse was converted to team offices, team spaces, and a private club for the Orioles. It is also used for private wedding receptions.
In the entire history of Camden Yards, [[Ken Griffey Jr.]], has been the only player to hit the warehouse with a home run. He did so in the 1993 MLB [[Home Run Derby (Major League Baseball)|Home Run Derby]], in which he tied [[Juan González (baseball)|Juan González]] before losing in a playoff. No player has accomplished the feat in a game.
==See also== * [[Longworth Hall|B & O Freight Terminal]], a similar structure in Cincinnati
==External links== *{{commonscat-inline|Baltimore and Ohio Warehouse}} *[https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&geocode=&q=B%26O+Warehouse&sll=39.310023,-76.587011&sspn=0.007953,0.014763&ie=UTF8&ll=39.284589,-76.618931&spn=0,359.985237&z=16&layer=c&cbll=39.283921,-76.619221&panoid=PMACrFsyixkFNkZ7C5FpSQ&cbp=12,245.19480537189293,,0,5 B&O Warehouse on Google Street View] *[http://explore.baltimoreheritage.org/items/show/324 Baltimore & Ohio Warehouse at Camden Yards]

{{Infobox building | image = BGEtower.jpg | caption = Entrance to building at 39 West Lexington Street (southeast corner with North Liberty Street) | location = 39 W. Lexington St.
[[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]] | coordinates = {{coord|39.2912|-76.6171|region:US-MD_type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | start_date = | completion_date = 1916 | architect = [[J. Harleston Parker|Parker, Thomas & Rice]] {{Infobox NRHP | name =Baltimore Gas and Electric Company Building | nrhp_type = | embed = yes | caption = | location= | locmapin = United States Baltimore#Maryland#USA | built =1916 | architect= | architecture= Beaux Arts, Skyscraper | added = December 29, 2003 | governing_body = Private | refnum=03001325{{NRISref|2008a}} }} | owner = | cost = | floor_area = | top_floor = | floor_count = 21 | references = {{emporis|118992}}{{skyscraperpage|19117}}{{structurae|s0021251}} | building_type = Residential apartments | architectural_style = [[Beaux-Arts architecture]] | antenna_spire = | roof = {{convert|88|m|abbr=on}} | elevator_count = | building_name = Baltimore Gas and Electric Company Building | former_name = Baltimore Gas & Electric Building
Consolidated Gas Company Building
Lexington Street Building
West Tower
Constellation Energy/BG&E Building | room_count = | unit_count = | engineer = | contractor = | developer = | management = }} The '''Baltimore Gas and Electric Company Building''' is a historic [[office building]] located at [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]], United States. It is the former headquarters of the old Consolidated Gas, Light and Electric Power Company of Baltimore City, which was a merger at the turn of the 20th century of the former century old Gas Light Company of Baltimore with several other formerly competing gas and electric power companies which had risen in the late 19th century, to form a single metropolitan wide unified utility system. In 1955, the old cumbersome Consolidated title was jettisoned and the utility rebranded as the [[Baltimore Gas and Electric|Baltimore Gas and Electric Company]] (BG&E). A 21-story [[skyscraper]] designed by the Boston and Baltimore-based architectural firm of [[Parker, Thomas and Rice]], and was constructed in 1916. Standing at {{convert|88|m|abbr=on}} it was tied with the [[Emerson Bromo-Seltzer Tower]] from 1916 to 1923 as the [[List of tallest buildings in Baltimore|tallest building in Baltimore]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} It was constructed with a structural steel skeleton and tile arch flooring structure. The exterior is clad with gray granite and gray and white marble from the first through third floors (including the mezzanine) and glazed [[terra cotta]] in a [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] Classical Style. The building includes sculptures at the fourth floor representing "knowledge", "light", "heat" and "power."{{cite book|last=Dorsey|first=John|author2=Dilts, James D.|title=A Guide to Baltimore Architecture|publisher=Tidewater Publishes|location=Centreville, Maryland|year=1981|edition=Second|page=57|isbn=0-87033-272-4}}{{cite web|url=https://mht.maryland.gov/secure/medusa/PDF/NR_PDFs/NR-1380.pdf |title=National Register of Historic Places Registration: Baltimore Gas and Electric Company Building|date=June 2003|accessdate=2016-03-01 |author=David M. Facenda|publisher=Maryland Historical Trust}} Baltimore Gas and Electric Company Building was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2003. A smaller addition was built in 1966, designed by Fisher, Nes, Campbell and Associates. It was purchased in 2006 and reopened in 2007 as luxury apartments complete with two penthouse levels by [[Southern Management Corporation]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{MHT url|id=1444|title=Baltimore Gas and Electric Company Building, Baltimore City}}, including photo from 2003, at Maryland Historical Trust {{Buildings in Baltimore timeline}} {{National Register of Historic Places in Maryland}} [[Category:Downtown Baltimore]] [[Category:Residential skyscrapers in Baltimore]] [[Category:Commercial buildings on the National Register of Historic Places in Baltimore]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1916]] [[Category:Beaux-Arts architecture in Maryland]] [[Category:Exelon]]

revision.text:
{{COI|date=July 2018}} {{advert|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox company |name = Blue Prism Group |logo = Blue_Prism_Company_Logo.png |logo_size = 200px |logo_caption = Logo as of 2017 |type = [[Public company|Public]] |traded_as = {{unbulleted list|{{London Stock Exchange|PRSM}}}} | ISIN = GB00BYQ0HV16 |founders = David Moss and Alastair Bathgate |industry = {{flatlist| * [[Robotic Process Automation]] Software * [[Information technology]] }} |homepage = {{URL|http://www.blueprism.com|www.blueprism.com}} |foundation = {{Start date and age|2001|07|26}} |location_country = [[Newton-le-Willows]], [[Merseyside]], UK }}
'''Blue Prism''' is the trading name of the '''Blue Prism Group''', a UK multinational software corporation that pioneered and makes enterprise [[robotic process automation]] software to eliminate low-return, high-risk, manual data entry and processing work. Blue Prism is headquartered in [[Newton-le-Willows]], [[Merseyside]], UK<ref name="AIMLaunch">{{Citation|title=Software Robots Pioneer Blue Prism Debuts on the London Stock Exchange’s AIM Market|publisher=Business Wire|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160315005923/en/Software-Robots-Pioneer-Blue-Prism-Debuts-London}}</ref> with regional offices in the US and Australia.<ref name="InnovCenter">{{Citation|title=Blue Prism Opens Global Technical Innovation Center|publisher=Business Wire|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170106005044/en/Blue-Prism-Opens-Global-Technical-Innovation-Center}}</ref><ref name="AUSOffice">{{Citation|title=Blue Prism Opens Global Technical Innovation Center|publisher=Business Wire|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170118006146/en/Blue-Prism-Expands-Presence-Asia-Pacific-Sales}}</ref> The company is listed on the London Stock Exchange AIM market.<ref name="AIMLaunch" />
==History== ===Formation=== Blue Prism was founded in 2001 by a group of process automation experts to develop technology that could be used to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of organisations.<ref name="AIMLaunch" /> Initially their focus was on the white collar back office where they recognised an enormous unfulfilled need for automation. The company was co-founded by Alastair Bathgate and David Moss<ref name="AIMLaunch" /> to provide a new business-led, more granular and economic approach that today is known as [[Robotic Process Automation]], or RPA. In doing so Blue Prism created a digital workforce. In 2003 Blue Prism’s first commercial product was launched.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} [[Co-operative Financial Services]] began using Blue Prism software in 2005, to automate manual processes in customer services.<ref name=cw-extends> {{cite news |last=Ashford |first=Warwick |date=August 29, 2007 |title=Co-operative bank extends automation with Blue Prism |url=http://www.computerweekly.com/news/2240082707/Co-operative-bank-extends-automation-with-Blue-Prism | work=[[Computer Weekly]] |location= |access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref>
===Robotic Process Automation=== [[Robotic Process Automation]] (RPA) is the application of technology that provides organizations with a digital workforce that follows rule-based business processes and interacts with the organisations systems in the same way that existing users currently do.<ref name="LSEBook">{{cite book |title=Service Automation: Robots and The Future of Work|publisher=London School of Economics|page= |isbn=0956414567 |author=Professors Leslie Willcocks and Mary Lacity}}</ref><ref name="TimesBPO">{{Citation|title=Times BPO Supplement|publisher=Raconteur|url=http://np.netpublicator.com/netpublication/n34908574}}</ref><ref name="TechChangingBPO">{{Citation|title=How is technology changing BPO?|publisher=Computer Weekly|url=http://www.computerweekly.com/blogs/inside-outsourcing/2012/06/how-is-technology-changing-bpo.htm }}</ref><ref name="HfSThreat">{{Citation|title=Robotic Automation Emerges as a Threat to Traditional Low Cost Outsourcing|publisher=HfS Research|url=http://www.hfsresearch.com/Robotic-Automation-as-Threat-to-Traditional-Low-Cost-Outsourcing|access-date=2017-02-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150921062911/http://www.hfsresearch.com/Robotic-Automation-as-Threat-to-Traditional-Low-Cost-Outsourcing#|archive-date=2015-09-21|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="ChappelERPA">{{Citation|title=Understanding Enterprise RPA: The Blue Prism Example|publisher=David Chappel & Associates|url=http://www.davidchappell.com/writing/white_papers/Understanding_Enterprise_RPA--The_Blue_Prism_Example_v1.0.pdf}}</ref><ref name="LSENewApproach">{{Citation|title=A new approach to automating services|publisher=London School of Economics|url=http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/68135/1/Willcocks_New%20approach_2016.pdf}}</ref><ref name="HFSUnderlings">{{Citation|title=Welcoming our robotic security underlings|publisher=HFS Research|url=https://www.hfsresearch.com/pointsofview/welcoming-our-robotic-security-underlings}}</ref> Blue Prism coined the term "robotic automation" in 2012.<ref name=rauto> {{cite news |last=Francis |first=Sam |date=March 15, 2016 |title=Virtual robots maker Blue Prism debuts on London stock market |url=http://roboticsandautomationnews.com/2016/03/15/virtual-robots-maker-blue-prism-debuts-on-london-stock-market/3511/ | work=Robotics and Automation News |location= |access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref>
===Floatation=== On March 18, 2016, the company floated on the [[London Stock Exchange]] AIM market, becoming a public company.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} With a market capitalization of £48.5 million, Blue Prism underwent an IPO in March 2016.<ref name=im-frost/> The company's shares rose 44 percent on the first day of trading on AIM, under CEO Alastair Bathgate.<ref name=ft-blue>{{cite news |last=Burgess |first=Kate |date=March 20, 2016 |title=Blue Prism rides the robot wave |url=https://www.ft.com/content/9e1fa3b2-ec59-11e5-bb79-2303682345c8 | work=[[Financial Times]] |location=United Kingdom |access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref> Customers include O2, Co-operative Bank and Fidelity Investment Management. By November 2016, it had offices in [[Chicago]] and [[Miami]], as well as the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name=ft-coop>{{cite news |last1=Bounds |first1=Andy |last2=Tighe |first2=Chris |date=November 23, 2016 |title=What businesses want from the Autumn Statement |url=https://www.ft.com/content/101e8858-b0a8-11e6-9c37-5787335499a0 | work=[[Financial Times]] |location=United Kingdom |access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref>
On January 6, 2017, Blue Prism announced it would open new offices in [[Austin, Texas]], while remaining based in [[London]]. At the time, it employed 86 people worldwide.<ref name=biz-theis> {{cite news |last=Theis |first=Michael |date=January 9, 2017 |title=Two more British tech sector firms open Austin offices |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/news/2017/01/09/two-more-british-tech-sectorfirms-open-austin.html | work=[[Austin Business Journal]] |location=Austin, Texas, United States |access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref> In March 2017, a group of shareholders sold stakes in Blue Prism. At the time, Blue Prism remained based in [[Merseyside]].<ref name=im-frost> {{cite news |last=Frost |first=Richard |date=March 24, 2017 |title=Growth fund sells Blue Prism stake |url=https://www.insidermedia.com/insider/northwest/growth-fund-sells-blue-prism-stake | work=[[Insider Media]] |location= |access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref> In June 2017, Blue Prism announced that a new version of its software would run on public clouds such as Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform. Previously, the software had run on customers' own servers.<ref name=fortune-blue>{{cite news |last=Darrow |first=Barb |date=June 6, 2017 |title=This Software Helps Bots Do Their Work |url=http://fortune.com/2017/06/07/blue-prism-bots/ | work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |location= |access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref>
==Blue Prism technology== Blue Prism is built on the [[Microsoft .NET Framework]]. It automates any application and supports any platform ([[mainframe]], [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[Windows Presentation Foundation|WPF]], [[Java (programming language)|Java]], web, etc.) presented in a variety of ways (terminal emulator, thick client, thin client, web browser, Citrix and web services). It has been designed for a multi-environment deployment model (development, test, staging, and production) with both physical and logical access controls. [https://tekslate.com/blue-prism-training/ Blue Prism RPA software] includes a centralized release management interface and process change distribution model providing high levels of visibility and control. Additional control is provided to the business via a centralised model for process development and re-use. The software supports regulatory contexts such as [[PCI-DSS]], [[HIPAA]] and [[Sarbanes–Oxley Act|SOX]], with a large number of controls in place to provide the necessary security and governance.
In 2016, Blue Prism received one of the top honors at the AIconics Awards, named as The Best Enterprise Application of AI.<ref name="AIConics">{{Citation|title=Blue Prism: Best Enterprise Application of AI|publisher=aibusiness.org|url=http://aibusiness.org/aiconics-award-winners-blue-prism-best-enterprise-application-of-ai-2/}}</ref><ref name="AIConics2">{{Citation|title=London 2016 AIConics Winners|publisher=theaiconics.com|url=http://theaiconics.com/2016-winners/}}</ref>
Blue Prism supports only "back-office" unattended robots and does not offer attended "front-office" robots.<ref name="Comparison of two RPA leaders BluePrism and UiPath">{{Citation|title=Comparison of two RPA leaders BluePrism and UiPath|publisher=blog|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/comparison-two-rpa-leaders-blueprism-uipath-jakub-vaňhara/}}</ref>
==Competition== The main competitors in the Robotic Process Automation market include UIPath and Automation Anywhere. <ref name="Blue Prism Competitors and Alternatives in Robotic Process Automation">{{Citation|title=Blue Prism Competitors and Alternatives in Robotic Process Automation|publisher=gartner.com|url=https://www.gartner.com/reviews/market/robotic-process-automatio-software/vendor/blue-prism/alternatives}}</ref> The independent market research company Forrester Research identified these three companies as leaders both in terms of their market presence as well as the quality of their offering in a 2017 study. <ref name="forrester-wave-robotic-process-automation">{{Citation|title=The Forrester Wave™: Robotic Process Automation, Q1 2017|publisher=forrester.com|url=https://www.edgeverve.com/wpcontent/uploads/2017/02/forrester-wave-robotic-process-automation.pdf}}</ref>
In April 2018, industry analyst firm [[Wikibon]] attempted to test Robotic Process Automation platforms noting: "we contacted three RPA vendors — Automation Anywhere, Blue Prism, and UiPath — to test and validate each of these propositions. Only one vendor, UIPath, responded."<ref name="Assessing RPA Time-to-Value">{{Citation|title=Assessing RPA Time-to-Value with UiPath|publisher=blog|url=https://wikibon.com/assessing-rpa-time-value-uipath/}}</ref>
==The digital workforce== Blue Prism’s digital workforce is built, managed and owned by the user or customer, spanning operations and technology, adhering to an enterprise-wide robotic operating model. It is code-free<ref name="HBR">{{Citation|title=What knowledge workers stand to gain from automation|publisher=Harvard Business Review|url=https://hbr.org/2015/06/what-knowledge-workers-stand-to-gain-from-automation}}</ref> and can automate any software in a non-invasive way. The digital workforce can be applied to automate processes in any department where clerical or administrative work is performed across an organization.<ref name="TEDxDavidMoss">{{Citation|title=White Collar Robots: The Virtual Workforce|publisher=TEDx Talks|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1SximAg9t4w}}</ref>
==Business and markets== Blue Prism has been deployed in a number of industries including banking, finance and insurance, consumer package goods, legal services, public sector, professional services, healthcare and utilities. <ref name="FY16Results">{{Citation|title=Blue Prism Group plc – Year end results for the twelve months ended 31st October 2016 |publisher=London Stock Exchange RNS|url=http://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/news/market-news/market-news-detail/PRSM/13104372.html}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.blueprism.com Blueprism.com]
[[Category:Business software]] [[Category:Automation software]] [[Category:Information economy]] [[Category:Companies established in 2001]]

revision.text:
{{overcoverage|date=June 2011}}
'''Body-centred countertransference''' involves a psychotherapist's experiencing the physical state of the patient in a clinical context.<ref>Louise Phillips, ''Mental Illness and the Body'' (2006) p. 134</ref> Also known as [[Countertransference#Body-centred countertransference|somatic countertransference]], it can incorporate the therapist's gut feelings, as well as changes to breathing, to heart rate and to tension in muscles.<ref>Su Fox, ''Relating to clients'' (2008) p. 142</ref>
==Various approaches==
[[Dance therapy]] has understandably given much weight to the concept of somatic countertransference.<ref>Patrizia Pallaro, 'Somatic countertransference', in ''Authentic Movement'' vol 2 (2007) Chap 7</ref> Jungian [[James Hillman]] also emphasised the importance of the therapist using the body as a sounding-board in the clinical context.<ref>Pallaro, p. 176</ref>
Post-[[Wilhelm Reich|Reichian]] therapies like [[bioenergetic analysis]] have also stressed the role of the body-centered countertransference.<ref>Katya Bloom, ''The Embodied Self'' (2006) p. 70</ref>
There is some evidence that [[Narcissism|narcissistic]] patients and those suffering from [[Borderline personality disorder]] create more intense embodied countertransferences in their therapists,<ref>Tamara Latawec, ''When the Professional is Personal'' (2008) p. 94</ref> their personalities favouring such non-verbal communication by impact<ref>Patrick Casement, ''Further Learning from the Patient'' (1990) p. 24</ref> over more verbalised, less somatic interactions.
==Orbach==
[[Susie Orbach]] has written emotively of what she described as "wildcat sensations in my own body...a wildcat countertransference"<ref>Susie Orbach, 'Speaking Bodies' in ''Bodies'' (London 2009) 48-76, p. 50-1</ref> in the context of body countertransference. She details her [[Joseph J. Sandler#Role responsiveness and actualization|role responsiveness]] to one patient who evoked in her what she called "an unfamiliar body experience...this purring, reliable and solid body"<ref>Orbach, p. 52-5</ref> to counterbalance the fragmented body image of the patient herself.
==The Irish experience== ===In female trauma therapists=== Irish psychologists at NUI Galway and University College Dublin<ref>Egan, J. & Carr, A. (2005). [[Burnout (psychology)|Burnout]] in female counsellor/therapists of the NCS: Studies I, II and III. Papers presented at the 35th Annual conference of the psychological society of Ireland, Derry, Nov 17-20th</ref><ref>Egan, J. & Carr, A. (2008). Body-centred countertransference in female [[trauma therapists]]. Eisteach, 8, 22-27.</ref> have recently begun to measure body-centred countertransference in female trauma therapists using their recently developed 'Egan and Carr Body-Centred Countertransference Scale' (2005), a sixteen symptom measure.<ref>http://www.lenus.ie/hse/bitstream/10147/121271/1/BodycentredCounter.pdf</ref>
Their research was influenced by developments in the psychotherapy world which was beginning to see a therapist's role in a therapeutic dyad as reflexive; that a therapist uses their bodies and 'self' as a tuning fork to understand their client's internal experience and to use this attunement as another way of being empathic with a client's internal world.<ref>Stone, M. (2006). The analyst's body as a tuning fork: Embodied resonance in countertransference. Journal of Analytical Psychology, 51, 109-124</ref><ref>Wosket, V. (1999). The therapeutic use of self. London: Routledge.</ref> Pearlman and Saakvitne's seminal book on [[vicarious traumatization]] and the effect of trauma work on therapists has also been an important directional model for all researchers studying the physical effects of trauma work on a therapist.<ref>Pearlman, L. A., & Saakvitne, K. W. (1995). Trauma and the therapist: Countertransference and vicarious traumatization in psychotherapy with incest survivors. New York: Norton</ref>
High levels of body-centred countertransference have since been found in both Irish female trauma therapists and clinical psychologists.<ref>Booth, A., Trimble, T., & Egan, J. (2010). Body-centred countertransference in a sample of Irish Clinical Psychologists. The Irish Psychologist, 36, 284-289.</ref> This phenomenon is also known as 'somatic countertransference' or 'embodied countertransference' and it links to how [[mirror neurons]] might lead to 'unconscious automatic somatic countertransference' as a result of [[postural mirroring]] by the therapist.<ref>Egan, J. & Carr, A. (2008). Body-centred countertransference in female trauma therapists. Eisteach, 8, 22-27</ref><ref>Rothschild, B. (2006). Help for the helper: self-care strategies for managing burnout and stress. London: W. W. Norton & Company.</ref>
Loughran (2002) found that 38 therapists out of 40 who had responded to a questionnaire (which was distributed to a sample of 124 therapists) on a therapist's use of body as a medium for transference and countertransference communication reported that they had experienced bodily sensations (nausea or churning stomach, sleepiness, shakiness, heart palpitations, sexual excitement, etc.) while in session with patients.<ref>Loughran, E. H. (2002). The therapists's use of body as a medium for [[transference]] and countertransference communication. Unpublished Doctor of Psychology Dissertation. Wright Institute: California.</ref>
===Frequency of symptom occurrence===
A list of the frequency of occurrence of body-centred countertransference symptoms reported by trauma therapists (Sample A: 35 Female Irish Trauma therapists<ref>Egan, J. & Carr, A. (2008). Body-centred countertransference in female trauma therapists. Eisteach, 8, 22-27.</ref>) and Irish clinical psychologists (Sample B: 87 Irish Clinical Psychologists<ref>Booth, A., Trimble, T., & Egan, J. (2010). Body-centred countertransference in a sample of Irish Clinical Psychologists. The Irish Psychologist, 36, 284-289.</ref>)in the previous six months 'when in-session with a client' is given below in order of frequency: {{Col-begin}} {{Col-2}} #Sleepiness (A; 92%, B; 76%) #Muscle Tension (A; 83%, B; 79%) #Yawning (A; 65%, B; 77%) #Unexpected shift in body (A; 77%, B; 57%) #Tearfulness (A; 71%, B; 61%) #Headache (A; 54%, B; 53%) #Stomach Disturbance (A; 41%, B; 46%) #Throat Constriction (A; 34%, B; 36%) {{Col-3}} #Raised Voice (A; 29%, B; 33%) #Dizziness (A; 26%, B; 19%) #Loss of voice (A; 32%, B; 18%) #Aches in joints (A; 37%, B; 18%) #Nausea (A; 23%, B; 18%) #Numbness (A; 29%, B; 15%) #Sexual Arousal (A; 26%, B; 11%) #Genital pain (A; 6%, B; 2%) {{Col-end}}
===Somatization===
A small but significant relationship was found between female trauma therapists' level of body-centred countertransference and number of sick leave days taken, suggesting a possible relationship between uncensored body-centred countertransference and [[somatization]]. This relationship was not however found in [[clinical psychologists]] who were working mainly with a non-trauma population. Therapists have noted the connection between a tendency for some clients to express emotional discomfort by focusing on [[bodily symptoms]] rather than being able to put their emotional distress into words.<ref>http://www.lenus.ie/hse/bitstream/10147/121822/1/SomatizationDis.pdf</ref> It is thought that such processes are more common in people who have experienced [[childhood abuse]] and trauma.<ref>Pribor, E. F., Yutzy, S. H., Dean, J. T., Wetzel, R. D. (1993). [[Briquet's syndrome]], dissociation and abuse. American Journal of Psychiatry, 150, 1507-1511.</ref>
Recent research which measured female [[genital arousal]] in response to rape cues found that women when listening to rape, consent or violence developed genital arousal more frequently than men. It also might explain the relatively frequent reported experience of sexual arousal amongst Irish female trauma therapists.<ref>Suschinsky, K. D. & Lalumiere, M. L. (2010). Prepared for anything? An investigation of female genital arousal in response to rape cues. Psychological Science OnlineFirst@ 10.1177/0956797610394660</ref> Further validation of body-centred countertransference in psychologists and therapists is on-going in both [[NUI Galway]] and Trinity College Dublin.
==Cautions==
Therapists have been warned against assuming too automatically that their body-feelings always involve somatic resonance to the client, as opposed to being produced from their own feelings/experiences - the same problem appearing with countertransference generally.<ref>Christiane Sanderson, ''Counselling Adult Survivors of Child Sexual Abuse'' (2006) p. 136-7 and p. 395</ref>
==See also== {{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Acting in]] * [[Alexithymia]] * [[Neutrality (psychoanalysis)|Analytic neutrality]] * [[Burnout (psychology)|Burnout]] * [[Compassion fatigue]] * [[Hysterical contagion]] * [[Mass psychogenic illness]] * [[Posttraumatic stress disorder]] * [[Somatization disorder]] * [[Therapeutic relationship]] * [[Traumatology]] }}
== References == {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== Kate White ed., ''Touch: Attachment and the Body'' (2004)
L. A Pearlman/K. W. Saakvitne, ''Trauma and the Therapist''
Robert Shaw, ''The Embodied Psychotherapist'' (2003)
==External links==
[https://web.archive.org/web/20120907051838/http://www.wttn.org.uk/ecthandout.pdf Michael Soth, 'Embodied countertransference']
[http://www.yobeely.f2s.com/articles/ect.html Nick Totton ed., 'Embodied countertransference']
{{DEFAULTSORT:Body-Centred Countertransference}} [[Category:Psychodynamics]] [[Category:Counseling]] [[Category:Stress]] [[Category:Motivation]]

revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Brendan Pereira|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Brendan Conan Pereira | image = BCP.png | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1928|11|23|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Mumbai]], Maharashtra, India | occupation = [[Creative director]], Designer | education = [[St. Isabel's, Mazagaon]], [[St. Mary's School, Mumbai]], [[Sir J.J. Institute of Applied Art]] | spouse = Therese | children = Ian, Maryan, Leon, and Gillian }} '''Brendan Conan Pereira''', also known as "BCP", is an Indian advertising executive.
==Early life and education== Pereira was Born on 23 November 1928, to Albert and Louise Pereira. He attended St. Isabel’s and St. Mary’s High School, both in Mazagaon, Mumbai. In 1945, he enrolled in [[Sir J.J. Institute of Applied Art]], to pursue a Diploma in Applied Art where he learnt block-making, lithography, and photography—as subsidiary subjects. In 1949, he joined L.A. Stronachs Advertising as an apprentice. Later he joined D.J. Keymer (Bensons, OBM, now O&M) as visualiser and assistant to [[art director]] P.N. Sarma.
In 1954, he married Therese (née Aranha). He left Bombay for the UK in 1956, for further education and experience. In London, he joined first Rapier Design, then Baron Moss, where he was later appointed [[Art Director]]. Subsequently, he joined C.Vernon’s and worked on a range of products. At the same time, he took courses at the [[Institute of Practitioners in Advertising]].
==Professional work== In 1960, he joined Aiyars Advertising, Bombay to work on the Beechams account they had just acquired. He spent a year with Beechams in London, to learn about their products and their marketing worldwide. 1961, he returned to Aiyars Advertising as [[Creative Director]] with the responsibility of all creative work as well as handling the Beecham account. Eventually Aiyars linked with LPE, London as LPE-Aiyars and he was elected to the board.
In March 1972, he left Aiyars Advertising to co-found Chaitra Advertising (now Leo Burnett). In 1983, he left Chaitra to form his own consultancy, GLIMA. Clarion Advertising appointed him as a Creative Consultant. In 1992, he supported the formation of Nova Advertising Palace with executives from Clarion and had a long association with this agency as Consultant, Managing Director and shareholder.
In 2001, he retired but continues to do charity work for the church and some NGOs.
==Recognition== He was President<ref>http://www.cagindia.in</ref> of [[Communication Arts Guild]] (CAG), [[Mumbai]] from 1976–1993, and was Inducted to their Hall of Fame in 1993. On 12 January 2014, he received a lifetime achievement award by the Cathedral of the Holy Name Archdiocese, Mumbai.
He lectured at The Advertising Club, taught at St. Xavier’s Institute of Communication in Mumbai, [[National Institute of Design]] in Ahmedabad, [[Tata Administrative Services]] in Pune, [[Jamnalal Bajaj Institute of Management Studies]] in Mumbai and The Packaging Institute on advertising, typography, and design. He was also the first Indian Member of the [[Art Directors Club]] of New York.
He published a book of the experiences in four decades of Advertising entitled, ''Changing Faces'' <ref>[http://www.ianpereira.com/tributes/ Changing Faces]</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.ianpereira.com/tributes/ Changing Faces (free pdf)]
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pereira, Brendan}} [[Category:Advertising people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1928 births]]

{{Multiple issues|{{Notability|Organizations|date=March 2010}} {{unreferenced|date=March 2010}} {{orphan|date=December 2010}} }} {{Infobox organization |name= British Georgian Chamber of Commerce |image= Logo of the British Georgian Chamber of Commerce.jpg |caption= |map= <!-- optional --> |msize= <!-- map size, optional, default 200px --> |malt= <!-- map alt text --> |mcaption= <!-- optional --> |abbreviation= BGCC |motto= |formation= {{Start date and years ago|2007|03|3}} |extinction= <!-- date of extinction, optional --> |type= <!-- GO, NGO, IGO, INGO, etc --> |status= <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> |purpose= Non-political trade body |headquarters= London, UK |location= London, UK |coords= <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> |region_served=[[United Kingdom]] and [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] |membership= |language= <!-- official languages --> |leader_title= Director |leader_name= Mako Abashidze |main_organ= <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> |parent_organization= <!-- if one --> |affiliations= <!-- if any --> |num_staff= |num_volunteers= |budget= |website= http://www.bgcc.org.uk/ |remarks= }}
The '''British Georgian Chamber of Commerce''' (BGCC) was founded in [[London]] by Lord Cromwell and Mako Abashidze in March 2007, as a non-political trade body to facilitate business growth and contacts at senior levels between Britain and Georgia. Both the Georgian Ambassador to the [[United Kingdom]] and the British Ambassador to [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] are honorary members of the organization's advisory council.
== Structure and membership == BGCC offers two types of membership: "founding members", who are members of the advisory council; and "business members", who participate in activities of the Chamber. Founding members of the BGCC include [[List of Ambassadors and High Commissioners to the United Kingdom|Cromwell]] and Abashidze as directors. As a bilateral company, BGCC carries out activity in the territories of the UK and Georgia. Its head office is located in London.
== History == The British Georgian Chamber of Commerce was founded in London by Lord Cromwell and Mako Abashidze in March 2007, as a non-political trade body, to facilitate business growth and contacts at senior levels between Britain and Georgia.
The inaugural event of the Chamber was held in London on 27 June 2007. Ambassadors Denis Keef and [[Gela Charkviani]] were present along with [[List of Ambassadors and High Commissioners to the United Kingdom|Giorgi Badridze]], the then Deputy Head of Mission, and currently outgoing Ambassador to the UK (as of 24 April 2013), as well as founding and business members, and companies which expressed their support and interest in the formation and development of BGCC's activities.
The opening event in Georgia was held in [[Tbilisi]] on 10 September 2007.
== Objectives == The main objectives of BGCC is to advise companies in the UK and Georgia on the business and financial markets each respective country, in order to establish contacts and facilitate business between each country. It hopes to achieve this goal through gathering relevant information efficiently and accurately, and by establishing and nurturing contacts.
== External links == *[http://www.bgcc.org.uk/ The British Georgian Chamber of Commerce] official site
[[Category:Political organisations based in London]] [[Category:Chambers of commerce]] [[Category:Georgia (country)–United Kingdom relations]]
{{UK-org-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} The '''capital resources, performance and scalability (CPS) model''' is a set of case analysis frameworks recommended by the Global Alliance for Strategy in collaboration with [[European School of Management and Technology]] and is widely used for assessing the sustainability and competitive ability of an organization.<ref>The INSEAD-Wharton Alliance on Globalizing: Strategies for Building Successful Global Businesses, Robert E. Gunther, Hubert Gatignon, John R. Kimberly, {{ISBN|0-521-83571-2}}</ref>
== Versions ==
The CPS model has several published versions, the latest revision being the one developed by Dr. P. V. Lele in August 2006.<ref>[http://www.esmt.org/eng/consulting/esmt-competition-analysis/ ESMT Competition Analysis – European School of Management and Technology<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Frameworks == The CPS model, in its most popular version, has five frameworks: * MAN-CHA * BOSH value ** SAC score ** ENPT score ** Y.U.K.U. Score * Differential derivation value (DVD) index * tri-VIN framework * Technology polarization at normal purchasing power
== Applications and criticism ==
CPS has been very useful in [[consumer durables]] and [[fast-moving consumer goods]] industries. However, the model fails to be effective in [[manufacturing industry]]. In several emerging businesses such as software services and [[business process outsourcing]], the DVD index returns a negative value, making the model redundant.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
== References ==
* ''Competition Analysis, ESMT'', http://www.esmt.org/eng/consulting/esmt-competition-analysis/ * Robert E. Gunther, Hubert Gatignon, John R. Kimberly, ''The INSEAD-Wharton Alliance on Globalizing: Strategies for Building Successful Global Businesses'', {{ISBN|0-521-83571-2}}
[[Category:Management systems]]

{{Infobox person |name = Chino Roces |image = Chino Roces.jpg |caption = |birth_name = Joaquin Pardo-Roces |birth_date = {{Birth date|1913|6|29}} |birth_place = [[Manila]], [[Insular Government of the Philippine Islands|Philippine Islands]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1988|9|30|1913|6|29}} |death_place = [[Manila]], [[Philippines]] |death_cause = Lymphatic cancer |other_names = |known_for = Founder of ''[[The Manila Times]]'' and [[TV5 Network|Associated Broadcasting Company]] |occupation = |spouse(s) = Pacita Carvajal |nationality = Filipino }}
'''Joaquin "Chino" Roces''' (June 29, 1913 – September 30, 1988) was the founder and owner of [[TV5 Network, Inc.|Associated Broadcasting Company]] and ''[[The Manila Times]]''.
==Early life== Chino Roces was born on June 29, 1913 to Alejandro "Moy" Roces and Antonia "Nena" Pardo from [[San Miguel, Manila]]. He has seven siblings; Ramon Roces, Alejandro "''Anding””Roces, Jr., Filomena "''Nenita'' " Roces de Verzosa, Isabel "''Bebeng''" Roces, Mercedes Roces, Rafael "''Tuti''" Roces, Antonia "''Chucha''" Roces de Prieto and Marcos "''Taling''" Roces.
He started his publishing career in his father's newspaper chain [[Tribune - La Vanguardia - Taliba|TVT]] (Tribune - La Vanguardia - Taliba) before [[World War II]]. Don Chino later headed the Roces family media empire composed of newspapers The [[Manila Times]], [[Daily Mirror]], [[Sunday Times]], [[Taliba]], [[Women's Magazine Variety]], Radio stations [[DZMT]] / [[DZWJ]] and TV Station [[The 5 Network|ABC Channel 5]]. He also organized media groups, the [[Philippine News Agency]] (PNA), and [[Philippine Press Institute]].
Don Chino was arrested and jailed when [[Martial law in the Philippines|Martial Law]] was imposed in 1972, together with [[Benigno Aquino Jr.|Ninoy Aquino]], [[Jose Diokno|Pepe Diokno]], [[Lorenzo Tanada]] and other journalists. As soon as he was released, he took to the streets to openly protest the Marcos government. After the assassination of Benigno "Ninoy" Aquino in 1983, he further intensified his protest and during a vigil on [[Mendiola]] Bridge, Don Chino was drenched by water cannons.
On October 15, 1985, Don Chino founded the [[Cory Aquino for President Movement]] (CAPM). It was launched in the National Press Club. He gathered over 1 Million Signatures from all over the nation to draft [[Corazon Aquino]] to run against Marcos.
After the [[People Power Revolution|EDSA revolution]] he returned to publishing, first joining forces with [[Geny Lopez]] in the [[Manila Chronicle]], and then later once more the publisher of the family owned The Manila Times.
On July 22, 1988, President Aquino conferred on him the [[Philippine Legion of Honor|Philippine Legion of Honor Award]] (degree of chief Commander) the highest honor the country can bestow to a civilian.
==Personal life== He was married to Dona Pacita Carvajal and had four children namely: Joaquin "''Joaqui''" Roces Jr., Arturo Roces, Edgardo "''Eddie''" C. Roces, and Rocio Rosalinda Antonia Roces.
==Death== He died of lymphatic cancer on September 30, 1988 at the age of 75 in Manila, Philippines.
==Images== <gallery> File:MendiolaStreetjf2529 08.JPG|"Tulay ng Kalayaan" Historical marker ("Freedom Bridge" or "Chino Roces Bridge") File:MendiolaStreetjf2545 10.JPG|"Chino Roces Bridge" File:MendiolaStreetjf2545 16.JPG|Facade of [[Mendiola Street]] </gallery>{{Commons category}} {{PLH Recipients}} {{TV5}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Roces, Chino}} [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:1988 deaths]] [[Category:Filipino businesspeople]] [[Category:Filipino media executives]] [[Category:People from San Miguel, Manila]] [[Category:Ateneo de Manila University alumni]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in the Philippines]] [[Category:TV5 Network executives]] [[Category:Filipino company founders]]

revision.comment: Importing Wikidata [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Romanian politician" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Romanian politician}} '''Ioan-Codruţ Şereş''' (born 2 August 1969) is a [[Romania]]n engineer and politician. A member of the [[Conservative Party (Romania)|Conservative Party]] (PC), he was a member of the [[Senate of Romania|Romanian Senate]] for [[Maramureş County]] from 2004 to 2008. In the [[Călin Popescu-Tăriceanu]] cabinet, he was [[Ministry of Public Finance (Romania)|Minister of Economy and Commerce]] from 2004 to 2006.
==Biography==
He was born in [[Zalău]], and from 1988 to 1993 attended the [[Technical Military Academy of Bucharest]], becoming a mechanical engineer and graduating first in his class. In 1999 he earned a [[Master of Business Administration]] through a programme organised by the [[University of Ottawa]], [[HEC Montréal]] and the [[Bucharest Academy of Economic Studies]]. From 1993 to 1999 he worked at the [[Ministry of National Defense (Romania)|Defence Ministry]], being assigned to the procurement department from 1996. From 1999 to 2004 he held management positions at three different firms, including as assistant director of [[Antena 1 (Romania)|Antena 1]] (1999-2000) and as director of business development and strategy at [[Grivco]] (2001-2003), both owned by [[Dan Voiculescu]], leader of the PC.<ref name="cvministru">{{ro icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20060525065056/http://www.gov.ro/guvernul/afis-ministru.php?ordcabinet=11 Curriculum vitae] at the Romanian Government site; accessed August 23, 2010</ref> In 2010, Şereş became president of Antena 1 and of [[Intact Media Group]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.romanialibera.ro/actualitate/media/codrut-seres-presedintele-antena-1-si-intact-production-191316.html "Codruţ Sereş, preşedintele Antena 1 şi Intact Production" ("Codruţ Sereş, President of Antena 1 and Intact Production")], ''România liberă'', 23 June 2010; accessed August 23, 2010</ref>
In 2001, Şereş joined the PUR (PC from 2005). In 2002, he became head of its department devoted to financing infrastructure projects for local PUR officeholders, and helped finance ten projects. In 2003 he became secretary general of the party, rising to vice president the following year, when he was also [[Romanian legislative election, 2004|elected]] senator.<ref name="cvministru"/> In the Senate, he sat on the following committees: budget, finance, banking and capital markets (2006-2008); equal opportunity (2006); and privatisation and administering state assets (2004-2006). He was also vice president of the body during one session.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.cdep.ro/pls/parlam/structura.mp?idm=115&cam=1&leg=2004 Parliamentary profile]; accessed August 23, 2010</ref> Additionally, he served as Economy Minister from December 2004 to December 2006,<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documentare.rompres.ro/guverne.php?i=12 Călin Popescu-Tăriceanu Government]; accessed August 23, 2010</ref> resigning when the PC withdrew its support from the government.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.dailybusiness.ro/stiri-finante-banci/pc-iese-de-la-guvernare-ministrul-economiei-demisioneaza-508 "PC iese de la guvernare, ministrul Economiei demisionează" ("PC Leaves Government, Economy Minister Resigns")], dailybusiness.ro, 3 December 2006; accessed August 23, 2010</ref> Around the same time, prosecutors from the [[Directorate for Investigating Organized Crime and Terrorism]] (DIICOT) opened an investigation into Şereş dealing with his relationship to the [[Bulgaria]]n consultant Stamen Stanchev. They charged he had granted insider information or otherwise used his position to help Stanchev facilitate the privatisation of [[Electrica]] South Muntenia, of the Romanian government's 8% holding in [[Petrom]], and of [[Romexterra Bank]], as well as the planned privatisation of the [[Turceni Energy Complex]], allegations that he denied.<ref>{{ro icon}} Cristian Stănescu, Georgeta Ghidovăţ, Simona Popa, Claudiu Târziu, [http://old.cotidianul.ro/dosarul_spionaj_in_ministere_tradatorul_ii_platea_intretinerea_spionului-18593.html "Dosarul Spionaj în ministere: 'Trădătorul' îi plătea întreţinerea 'spionului'" ("Espionage in Ministries Dossier: 'The Traitor' Paid Housing for 'The Spy'")] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726051523/http://old.cotidianul.ro/dosarul_spionaj_in_ministere_tradatorul_ii_platea_intretinerea_spionului-18593.html |date=2011-07-26 }}, ''Cotidianul'', 26 November 2006; accessed August 23, 2010</ref> In 2009, a formal criminal case was opened against Şereş, who was indicted for treason and organised crime; five other persons are involved in the case, including Şereş' former ministerial colleague [[Zsolt Nagy (politician)|Zsolt Nagy]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.mediafax.ro/social/codrut-seres-si-zsolt-nagy-deferiti-justitiei-in-dosarul-privatizarilor-4112767 "Codruţ Şereş şi Zsolt Nagy, deferiţi justiţiei în dosarul privatizărilor" ("Codruţ Şereş and Zsolt Nagy, Handed over to the Justice System in the Privatisations Dossier")], Mediafax, 30 March 2009; accessed August 23, 2010</ref> In 2013, he was convicted of the charges and sentenced to six years' imprisonment.<ref>{{ro icon}} Mihaela Cojocariu, [http://adevarul.ro/news/eveniment/dosarul-tradare-fostii-ministrii-codrut-seres-zsolt-nagy-isi-afla-marti-sentinta-1_529cdd29c7b855ff5666d07c/index.html "Fostul ministru Codruţ Sereş, condamnat la 6 ani de închisoare în dosarul în care este acuzat de trădare" ("Former Minister Codruţ Sereş, Sentenced to 6 Years' Imprisonment in the Case in Which He Is Accused of Treason")], ''Adevărul'', 3 December 2013; accessed December 3, 2013</ref> In 2015, upon the exhaustion of his appeals, he was given a sentence of four years and eight months and incarcerated. Additionally, he was sentenced to four years' imprisonment in a case involving a corruption scandal at the state hydroelectric company, but appealed that ruling.<ref>{{ro icon}} Mihaela Cojocariu, [http://adevarul.ro/news/eveniment/dosarul-privatizari-strategice-fostul-ministru-codrut-seres-si-ar-putea-afla-marti-sentinta-definitiva-1_54c7497e448e03c0fdffbe21/index.html "Foştii miniştri Codruţ Şereş şi Zsolt Nagy, încarceraţi la Penitenciarul Rahova după ce au fost condamnaţi la închisoare" ("Former Ministers Codruţ Şereş and Zsolt Nagy, Incarcerated at Rahova Penitentiary after Being Sentenced to Prison")], ''Adevărul'', 27 January 2015; accessed January 31, 2015</ref> The ruling was also upheld in early 2016 by the [[High Court of Cassation and Justice|High Court]].<ref name="revista22.ro_2016-02-29">{{Citation | url=http://revista22.ro/70252398/fostul-ministru-al-economiei-codru-ere-condamnat-definitiv-la-4-ani-cu-executare.html| title=Fostul ministru al Economiei, Codruț Șereș, condamnat definitiv la 4 ani cu executare| newspaper=Revista 22| date= 2016-02-29| author=Tudor Despina| accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref>
In 1995, Şereş married Adina Zugravu, with whom he had a daughter in 1996 and whom he divorced in 2004. The catering firm of which she was director signed a number of [[no-bid contracts]] with the Economy Ministry while her former husband was in charge there. In 2006, he married Lorina Pop, the daughter of a [[Baia Mare]] businessman who later became a personal adviser to Şereş.<ref>{{ro icon}} Georgeta Ghidovăţ, George Lăcătuş, [http://old.cotidianul.ro/cum_sa_ti_intretii_nevasta_cazul_codrut_seres-26362.html "Cum să-ţi întreţii nevasta: cazul Codruţ Şereş" ("How to Keep Your Wife: the Codruţ Şereş Case")] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222170655/http://old.cotidianul.ro/cum_sa_ti_intretii_nevasta_cazul_codrut_seres-26362.html |date=2011-02-22 }}, ''Cotidianul'', 22 May 2007; accessed August 23, 2010</ref>
== See also == * [[List of corruption scandals in Romania]]

{{about|a history of one corporation|the history of all corporations|History of companies}} A '''corporate history''' is a [[chronological]] account of a [[business]] or other co-operative organization. Usually it is produced in written format but it can also be done in audio or [[audiovisual]]ly. Thousands of companies across the industrialized world have put their stories to paper, albeit in their own unique ways – from relatively benign, albeit colorful chronicles, usually written for the private [[archive]]s of founding families, to titles with well-defined corporate applications. Corporate histories in the [[United States]] have been particularly prolific, those in the [[UK]] less so.
== History == In the late 19th century, corporate histories were initially written by [[Victorian era]] businessmen, either the founder of a company himself, members of the surviving family owners or long-serving [[employee]]s. Rather than being [[wiktionary:sequential|sequential]] histories, as is now done, many of them were [[diary]]-type personal recollections or short, superficial [[public relations]] exercises. One of the earliest corporate histories, that of a publishing company in the UK called the Catnach Press, was done in 1886. A notable early US corporate history, published in 1902, was that of [[Standard Oil]].
Academic involvement probably started in 1924 when [[George Unwin]] and co-author George Taylor published a detailed history, ''Samuel Oldknow and the Arkwrights: The Industrial Revolution at Stockport and Marple''. It was published by the Manchester University Press.
Between the [[World War]]s, the majority of business histories, and especially in the UK, were house histories, consisting mainly of reminiscences and anecdotes. Only a tiny handful of serious work existed using business records which had found their way into museums, county record offices or the private possession of collectors. Corporate histories were typically unplanned. Relevant records were often discovered by chance and deemed interesting enough to turn into historical narratives which were funded either by the family descendants of the long-dead businessmen in question or, less frequently, the author in association with a publisher. They had one thing in common - they were generally records of companies that had died or otherwise dropped out of sight. One exception occurred In 1938, when the [[Bank of England]] commissioned a two-volume 250-year anniversary history. Written by [[J. H. Clapham]], professor of economic history at Cambridge, it took six years to produce. It was a deliberately celebratory vehicle for this famous British institution.
Modern corporate history took a large conceptual step in 1947 when the then chairman of [[Unilever]], Geoffrey Heyworth (later [[Geoffrey Heyworth, 1st Baron Heyworth|Lord Heyworth]]) approached [[G. N. Clark]], who had led the national campaign against the destruction of business records, for his advice on writing the history Unilever, an Anglo-Dutch manufacturing company. Clark, who had just become a professor of modern history at Oxford, suggested as author a younger colleague, [[Charles Wilson (historian)|Charles Wilson]]. The result was a classic, two-volume work that transformed the writing of business history in the UK from a public relations exercise into a reputable branch of scholarship. Wilson's work, about one of western Europe's most important companies, made him the father of modern corporate histories in the UK.
== Current practices ==
The majority of books written today are PR projects expressly designed to celebrate important anniversaries. There are also fewer: More histories of [[United Kingdom|British]] companies were being produced in the last year of the 19th century than were published in the last year of the 20th century.
Many more corporate histories are used in the education system of the US than in the UK and other countries.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}
Many companies see their corporate histories as effective purveyors of long-term [[organizational memory]] and especially suitable for transmitting strategy. As such it can provide an efficient induction/educational tool for transient employees in the highly [[labour market flexibility|flexible labor market]]. Corporate historians collect and catalog materials and disseminate information for internal use. "When people think of an archives, they tend to think of the [[National Archives]] in Washington," Dave Smith, the manager of [[Walt Disney Co.]]'s multimillion-piece collection of artifacts, said in 2003. "But a lot of organizations maintain them, including businesses."<ref>Kevin Markey, [http://www.usaweekend.com/03_issues/031123/031123historians.html "The incredible value of everyday things: From soda to soap flakes, even mundane objects have blue-chip appeal"], ''USA Today'' (weekend), 23 November 2003</ref>
Perhaps the largest corporate archive ever assembled is that of [[AT&T]], which began gathering historical material in 1921. As of 1999, its collection was overseen by a full-time staff of 11 people, and included {{convert|50000|ft|m}} of documents; 800,000 still photos; 12,000 various gadgets and artifacts, some of them dating back to Alexander Graham Bell; and 16,000 films and videos about AT&T.<ref>David Stamps, [http://www.allbusiness.com/services/educational-services/4276767-1.html "The Next Wave of the Future: History"], ''Training'' magazine, 1 December 1999</ref>
==See also==
*[[Organizational memory]] (OM) *[[Corporate culture]] *[[Corporate memory]]
==References== <references/>
== External links == *[http://www.archivists.org/ Society of American Archivists] *[http://www.nccjapan.net//shashiwiki/ Shashi Wiki, Bibliographis recods of Japanese Coroparate history books]
== Further reading == *Dahlstrom, Neil, “Perceptions and Realities: Dilemmas of a Corporate Historian,” ''AASLH History News'', 60 (Autumn 2005), pp 12–15 *Arnold Kransdorff, ''Corporate Amnesia'', Butterworth Heineman, 1998. *Arnold Kransdorff, ''Corporate DNA'', Gower Publishing, 2006. *"[http://www.economist.com/business/displaystory.cfm?story_id=9767599 Corporate History: The Merits of Looking Backward,]" ''The Economist,'' 6 September 2007. *"[https://web.archive.org/web/20110519140545/http://feedroom.businessweek.com/?fr_story=66a1534d180cba6de0d27d48ceb0c20fa72611bd&rf=sitemap History in Advertising: Using Brand History To Sell Products,]" ''BusinessWeek,'' 8 January 2007. *"[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d4ac9ada-5917-11dd-a093-000077b07658.html A Rummage Through the Corporate Attic,]" ''The Financial Times,'' 24 July 2008. *"[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/0e00283a-649c-11dd-af61-0000779fd18c.html?nclick_check=1 Celebrate the Past by Looking Forward,]" ''The Financial Times,'' 7 August 2008.
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Corporate History}} [[Category:Knowledge management]] [[Category:Company histories| ]]

revision.text:
'''David Stewart Dawson''' (1849 – 6 August 1932), frequently referred to as '''Stewart Dawson''', was an [[Australia]]n manufacturing jeweller and property tycoon born in [[Aberdeenshire]], Scotland.<ref name="Carters">[http://www.carters.com.au/index.cfm/index/5116-stewart-dawson-and-co-silver-and-precious-objects/ silver and precious objects - Stewart Dawson & Co<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
He served his apprenticeship in [[Dufftown]]<ref name="Carters" /> in [[Banffshire]] then founded a successful retail watchmaking and jewellery business in [[Liverpool]], England in 1871 after moving there age 22,<ref name="Carters" /> with shops in most large cities in Great Britain, aided by the slogan "Who watches the Police?".<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16887586 ''Sydney Morning Herald'' 12 August 1932]</ref> after winning a tender to supply watches for the Liverpool Police. Advertising in Australian newspapers brought so much business he decided to move there and emigrated in 1886. He founded the business of Stewart Dawson and Co. in [[Sydney]] and soon had branches in [[Melbourne]], and [[Auckland]] and [[Dunedin]] in [[New Zealand]] and [[Regent Street]] in London. After making the company a [[limited liability company]] in 1907, Dawson sold the company in 1931 to RHO Hills<ref name="Carters"/> [[department store]] (now [[House of Fraser]]).<ref>[http://www.housefraserarchive.ac.uk/company/?id=c2682 HOUSE OF FRASER Archive :: Company: RHO Hills Ltd<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The resulting company operated until 'around 1935'.<ref name="Carters" /><ref name="SilCltn">[http://www.silvercollection.it/electroplatesilverD.html English electroplate silver: marks and hallmarks of British silver plate: Da-Dh<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
He dealt extensively in inner-city real-estate, including some of the most significant transactions in Australian history. Anticipating the [[Great Depression]], he converted much of his property (valued around £1,000,000) from ownership to rental.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article4467152 obituary ''The Argus'' 8 August 1932]</ref> One significant property he owned was half of the [[Strand Arcade]] ([[Pitt Street]] end). This peculiar arrangement was to have far-reaching consequences as a result of piecemeal development and inconsistent maintenance.<ref>[http://www.dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/strand_arcade Strand Arcade<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
He was noted for his contribution to the [[First World War|war]] effort, and served on many committees.
He founded the Ambassadors Restaurant in 1923, long one of the most fashionable in Sydney.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article21979177 ''Brisbane Courier'' 8 August 1932]</ref>
<!-- His heirs included his wife Harriet Stewart Dawson, sons Percy Stewart Dawson (d. 1947), Norman Stewart Dawson (appointed Major, won VC, killed in car crash 1940) and Stuart Stewart Dawson, daughters Lila Arnold, Vanna Jerrard (not Gerrard) and Bertha Verral (not Verrai) and grand-daughter Joyce Verral. (The above references contain some typos). More details at http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16969689 Grandson David Stewart Dawson jr (son of Stuart) was subject of many news items inappropriate for Wikipedia --> He had a head office, 'The Treasure House' (built 1907) in [[Hatton Garden]], London and homes in [[Potts Point, New South Wales|Potts Point]] and [[Palm Beach, New South Wales|Palm Beach, Sydney]], a villa in [[Monte Carlo]] and a three-storey country mansion, "Bon Accord" in [[Springwood, New South Wales|Springwood]] in the [[Greater Blue Mountains Area|Blue Mountains]], close to [[Norman Lindsay]]'s home.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.carters.com.au/index.cfm/index/5116-stewart-dawson-and-co-silver-and-precious-objects/ |title= Stewart Dawson and Co: Silver and precious objects |publisher= Carters Antiques = }}</ref>
On his death the Monte Carlo villa went to his widow, Harriet Stewart Dawson (née McNab) (1864–1945) who married Prince Michal Radziwill, "Ordynat" (entailed estate holder) of the Palace and estate of Antonin in Ostrow County, Poland (1870–1955) in 1938.<ref> Supreme Court of New South Wales, Australia Probate Packet for the Estate of the late Princess Radziwill </ref> "Bon Accord" was kept as a guest house by his heirs, managed by [[Hugh D. McIntosh]], but burned down in 1937.
Today Stewart Dawson's is owned by New Zealand-Australian retail company the [[James Pascoe Group]],<ref name="SDAbout">[http://stewartdawsons.co.nz/about-us Stewart Dawsons<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728090624/http://stewartdawsons.co.nz/about-us |date=2013-07-28 }}</ref> acting as the groups's luxury jeweller in New Zealand.<ref name="SDAbout" /> The Stewart Dawson's brand is no longer in used in Australia, however thirteen stores remain across New Zealand.<ref name="SDAbout" /> Even today there is still a branch in [[Wellington, New Zealand| Wellington's]] historic [[Stewart Dawson's Building]] (colloquially known as ''Stewart Dawsons Corner''),<ref name="SDAbout" /> built by Dawson for the firm in 1901.
==References== {{Commons category|Stewart Dawsons}} {{reflist|30em}}
