revision.text:
{{Infobox NFL player |name=Don Coleman |image= |image_size= |alt= |caption= |number= |position=[[Linebacker]], [[Fullback (American football)|fullback]], [[defensive end]] |birth_date={{Birth date|1952|1|11}} |birth_place=[[Toledo, Ohio]] |death_date= |death_place= |high_school = Toledo St. John |height_ft = 6 |height_in = 2 |weight_lbs = 222 |college=[[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]] |draftyear=1974 |draftround=16 |draftpick=398 |pastteams= * [[New Orleans Saints]] (1974–1975) * [[New York Jets]] (1976–1977) |pfr=ColeDo20.htm }} '''Donald Alvin Coleman''' (born January 11, 1952) is an American entrepreneur, advertising executive and a pioneer in the growing field of multicultural advertising. Coleman is the founder, chairman and CEO of [[GlobalHue]], the largest multicultural advertising agency in the United States, working with blue chip brands and organizations to communicate with African-American, Asian and Hispanic consumers. He is also a former [[American football]] player, having played [[college football]] at the [[University of Michigan]] from 1971 to 1973 and professional football for the [[New Orleans Saints]] and [[New York Jets]] from 1974 to 1978.
==Early years== Coleman was born in [[Toledo, Ohio]] in 1952,<ref name=PFR/> and grew up in that city's [[Old West End District (Toledo, Ohio)|Old West End]] neighborhood. His mother, Dorothy Coleman, worked for the [[Department of Housing and Urban Development]], and his father, Augustus Coleman, worked as a [[skycap]] for [[United Airlines]] and as a janitor at a library.<ref name=NYT/>
At the suggestion of teachers at his public school, who told his parents that Coleman was not sufficiently challenged, he transferred to [[St. John's Jesuit High School and Academy]]. He attended St. John's from 1966 to 1970 where he excelled in academics and sports. Coleman was an All-City and All-State running back for St. John's and was recruited by multiple colleges to play football. He later recalled: "When it came time to select a university, I had about 20 coaches visiting the house, talking up their programs. I chose the University of Michigan. I received a full scholarship."<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|author=Don Coleman|title=Boss: Lessons From the Gridiron|newspaper=The New York Times|date=April 17, 2010|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/18/jobs/18boss.html}}</ref>
==University of Michigan== Coleman enrolled at the [[University of Michigan]] in 1970 on a football scholarship. He played [[college football]] for the [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan Wolverines]] under head coach [[Bo Schembechler]] from 1971 to 1973. Coleman began the 1971 season as a backup [[Fullback (American football)|fullback]], but Schembechler moved him to [[defensive end]] in late September 1971.<ref>{{cite news|title=Michigan Shifts Coleman To End|newspaper=The Blade, Toledo, Ohio|date=September 29, 1971|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nMlOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3AEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7556,4727795&dq=don-coleman+michigan&hl=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=U-M's Grambau Making Comeback|newspaper=The Owosso Argus-Press|date=September 29, 1972|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nUkiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4aoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=883,2976106&dq=don-coleman+michigan&hl=en}}</ref> Coleman played at defensive end from 1972 to 1973 and helped the Wolverines tie for first place in the [[Big Ten Conference]] both years.<ref>{{cite web|title=1972 Football Team|publisher=University of Michigan, Bentley Historical Library|url=http://bentley.umich.edu/athdept/football/fbteam/1972fbt.htm}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=1973 Football Team|publisher=University of Michigan, Bentley Historical Library|url=http://bentley.umich.edu/athdept/football/fbteam/1973fbt.htm}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=University of Michigan All-time Rosters Search Page |publisher=University of Michigan, Bentley Historical Library |url=http://141.211.39.65/allroster/fbsearch.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928200732/http://141.211.39.65/allroster/fbsearch.htm |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }}(Enter "Coleman" for last name and "Donald" for first name on the search page, and press enter)</ref> Although still listed as a defensive end, Schembechler described Coleman's role as follows in 1973: "In our defense we use a flop-end. So Coleman is actually a pro linebacker. He has to cover the pass as part of his responsibility today more so than normal."<ref>{{cite news|title='Cute' defenders make the big play|newspaper=The Michigan Daily|date=September 25, 1973|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ORZKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tx4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=3269,1342308&dq=don-coleman+michigan&hl=en}}</ref> Coleman had 51 tackles and 52 assists for the Wolverines.<ref name=Stat>{{cite web |title=Michigan Football Statistic Archive Query Page |publisher=University of Michigan |url=http://stats.ath.umich.edu/football/footstart.php |accessdate=July 20, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112175906/http://stats.ath.umich.edu/football/footstart.php |archivedate=November 12, 2007 |df= }}(To access Coleman's record, enter "Don" as his first and "Coleman" as his last name in the main search page. Then click on "Display Stats By Season" to access his game-by-game and season-by-season results.)</ref>
==Professional football== Coleman was drafted by the [[New Orleans Saints]] in the 16th round (398th overall pick) of the [[1974 NFL Draft]]. He played two seasons for the Saints in 1974 and 1975, appearing in 27 NFL games.<ref name=PFR>{{cite web|title=Don Coleman|publisher=pro-football-reference.com|url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/C/ColeDo20.htm}}</ref> Coleman was cut by the Saints in August 1976.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Scoreboard|newspaper=Daily Sentinel|date=August 5, 1976|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=w9JDAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qq8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=3541,1958810&dq=don-coleman+orleans&hl=en}}</ref> He signed as a free agent with the [[New York Jets]] shortly after being released by the Saints,<ref>{{cite news|title=Coleman Is Signed|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 21, 1976|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1976/08/21/140224372.pdf}}</ref> but he missed the entire [[1976 NFL season]] with a left knee injury. In August 1977, Coleman underwent surgery on his right knee,<ref>{{cite news|title=Knee surgery|newspaper=The Spokesman-Review|date=August 27, 1977|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lDxOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1u0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2496,4697082&dq=don-coleman+york+jets&hl=en}}</ref> and he was placed on injured reserve status.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rookie Leads Giants To Win|newspaper=The Evening News|date=August 30, 1977|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=diBgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UW4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=4790,5152387&dq=don-coleman+york+jets&hl=en}}</ref> The Jets released Coleman in June 1978.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sports Transactions|newspaper=The Sumter Daily Item|date=June 17, 1978|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=H4YiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FKoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4301,6923261&dq=don-coleman+york+jets&hl=en}}</ref>
==Advertising career== While recovering from football injuries, Coleman obtained an [[M.B.A.]] degree in marketing from [[Hofstra University]] in New York in 1976.<ref name=Hist/> In 1978, he was hired as an assistant account executive at the [[Campbell-Ewald]] advertising agency in Detroit. He later recalled: "I was the only black person in account management in the office. It was boring work, but I was speedy and accurate, persevered and became a full account executive."<ref name=NYT/> In 1983, he became senior vice president and management supervisor on the [[Chevrolet]] account.<ref name=NYT/>
Coleman next began a career in advertising directed to minority communities. He was hired in 1983 as a senior vice president and account director for Burrell Advertising, a Chicago firm specializing in advertising to minorities.<ref name=NYT/>
In 1988, he formed Don Coleman Associates, which became Don Coleman Advertising in 1991. He sold a minority interest in the company and bought two additional agencies, one focused on the Asian-American market (Innovasia Communications) and one focused on the Hispanic market (Montemayor y Asociados). He combined the companies into [[GlobalHue]], specializing in a culture based approach to marketing. He is the chairman and chief executive of GlobalHue.<ref name=NYT/>
In 2009, GlobalHue's capitalized billings were $833.7 million. The company has approximately 300 employees in [[Southfield, Michigan]] and New York City. Its clients include Subway, the United States Navy, U.S. Census 2010, Verizon Wireless, Merck & Co., Inc., Walmart and Chrysler Group.<ref name=Hist>{{cite web|title=Donald Coleman|publisher=The History Makers|url=http://www.thehistorymakers.com/biography/biography.asp?bioindex=1008&category=Businessmakers&occupation=Advertising%20Executive&name=Don%20Coleman}}</ref> In 2009, GlobalHue was named "Multicultural Advertising Agency of the Decade" by ''[[Adweek|Advertising Week magazine]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=MULTICULTURAL AGENCY OF THE DECADE: GlobalHue|publisher=Advertising Week|url=http://www.bestofthe2000s.com/multicultural-agency-of-the-decade.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316022032/http://www.bestofthe2000s.com/multicultural-agency-of-the-decade.html|archivedate=2012-03-16|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Mike Chapman|title=Q&A: GlobalHue's Don Coleman|publisher=Advertising Week|date=January 14, 2010|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/qa-globalhues-don-coleman-101319}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.blackenterprise.com/business/business-news/2009/12/15/globalhue-named-multicultural-agency-of-the-decade|title=Making Cultural Connections|publisher=Black Enterprise}}</ref> In 2010, ''[[Black Enterprise]]'' magazine named GlobalHue the BE 100 Advertising Agency of the Year, an honor that GlobalHue also received in 1998 and 2003.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.blackenterprise.com/small-business/2010/05/19/watch-2010-be100s-award-winners |title=WATCH: 2010 BE 100s Award Winner|publisher=Black Enterprise|date=May 19, 2010}}</ref> Coleman's daughter, Kelli Coleman, has also worked for GlobalHue since 2002 and is the vice president for business development.<ref>{{cite news|title=Twenty in the Twenties: Kelli Coleman, 23|publisher=Crain's Detroit|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/apps/pbcs.dll/dcce?Site=CD&Date=20080331&Module=10&Kategori=twenties&Class=101&Type=2008Winners&ID=1018065&Selected=5&nomdcache=1&nocache=1}}</ref>
In 2009, Coleman launched The Coleman Entrepreneurial Scholarship (CES), which strives to promote entrepreneurship as a career choice among college students of ethnic backgrounds, particularly African-American and Hispanic.<ref>http://www.blackenterprise.com/b-e-100s-rename-test/be100s-news/2009/02/03/advertising-mogul-creates-scholarship-to-promote-entrepreneurialism/</ref> CES awards $50,000 in scholarships annually.<ref>http://www.targetmarketnews.com/storyid02040903.htm</ref>
Coleman is also a member of the External Advisory Board at the A.C. Nielsen Center Marketing Research Business School, the Board of Visitors at ''[[Howard University|The Howard University John H. Johnson School of Communications]]'', and the Board of Trustees for the ''[[Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maah-detroit.org/eboard.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100713111948/https://www.maah-detroit.org/eboard.html |archivedate=2010-07-13 |df= }}</ref> and the Louis Carr Internship Foundation. Since 1999, he has served as vice chairman of the ''[[National Action Network|National Action Network (NAN)]]'', where he is a contributor to the organization's fundraising initiatives.
==Honors== *2010 Best of Black Business Advertising Award *2010 Ranked #31 in the list of the "Top 40 Titans: The Most Powerful African Americans in Business" by ''[[Black Enterprise]]'' magazine *2009 Moss Kendrix Marketer Award from the National Alliance of Market Developers
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.globalhue.com GlobalHue]

Imperial, if Imperial (metric) is desired--> | area_footnotes = <ref name=fact/> | area_total_km2 = 0.98 | area_land_km2 = <!--See table @ Template:Infobox Settlement for details on automatic unit conversion--> | area_water_km2 = <!-- Population -----------------------> | population_as_of = 2011 | population_footnotes = | population_note = Based on data for census tract 5350401.18<ref>This census track includes some area that are not considered as part of Downtown Markham, though this "extra" area is largely uninhabited and are mostly of industrial lands.</ref> | population_total = 3452<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2011/dp-pd/prof/details/page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo1=CT&Code1=2140&Geo2=CMA&Code2=535&Data=Count&SearchText=L6G1B3&SearchType=Begins&SearchPR=01&B1=All&Custom=&TABID=2|title=Statistics Canada 2011 Census Tract Profile for CT 5350401.18|year=2011|accessdate=2015-07-06}}</ref> | population_density_km2 = <!-- General information ---------------> | timezone = [[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Standard Time]] | utc_offset = -5 | timezone_DST = [[Eastern Daylight Time]] | utc_offset_DST = -4 | coordinates = {{coord|43.85|-79.32|region:CA-ON|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | elevation_footnotes = <!--for references: use<ref> </ref> tags--> | elevation_m = <!-- Area/postal codes & others --------> | postal_code_type = [[Canadian postal codes]] | postal_code = [[List of L postal codes of Canada|L6G]] | area_code = [[Area code 905/289|905]], [[Area code 905/289|289]] | website = [http://www.downtownmarkham.ca Downtown Markham] | footnotes = }}
'''Downtown Markham''' is the [[central business district]] of [[Markham, Ontario|Markham]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] currently being developed. It is located within Markham Centre and [[Unionville, Ontario|Unionville]] and is proposed to serve as the heart of Markham. <!-- This may be a crystal ball. -->Businesses in the district are expected to employ as many as 16,000 individuals,<ref name=GCL>{{cite web|url=http://www.guelphcivicleague.ca/page.php?p=55|title=Downtown Markham Makeover|accessdate=2008-06-16|author=Guelph Civic League}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name=TheStar>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/comment/columnists/article/245107|title=Digging for an elusive dream|accessdate=2008-06-16|author=The Toronto Star | work=The Star | date=2007-08-11}}</ref> and it may house as many as 10,000 residents.<ref name=glance>{{cite web|url=http://www.downtownmarkham.ca/pdfs/FS-At%20a%20Glance.pdf|title=Downtown Markham Facts at a glance|date=March 2006|accessdate=2007-10-12|author=Remington Group, and the Town of Markham|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061005120132/http://www.downtownmarkham.ca/pdfs/FS-At%20a%20Glance.pdf|archivedate=2006-10-05|df=}}</ref> The development will have a high density of residential, retail, commercial and mixed-use structures. The community is being developed, built and wholly financed by The [[Remington Group Inc]].
==Description== {{unreferenced section|date=May 2015}} Downtown Markham is a planned urban hub and the largest planned mixed-use development in Canada. The development spans 243 acres and is situated in one of the fastest growing regions in the province. It will be the commercial & financial district within Unionville at the center of the city of Markham, and will consist of a mix of residential, office and retail uses.
Two million square feet of retail space will include international retailers, local shops, restaurants and entertainment venues. Downtown Markham will also offer more than 3.4 million square feet of office space in a commercial district adjacent to [[Ontario Highway 407|Highway 407]].
The vibrant urban centre is being designed and developed following sustainable guidelines, including energy efficient power sources and LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) certified residential and commercial projects. Aside from allowing greater density, the development also enjoys 72 acres of natural and landscaped green space, improved walkability and easy access to public transit, including [[Viva Rapid Transit]] and [[GO Transit]].
Downtown Markham refers to an area south of [[Uptown Markham, Ontario|Uptown Markham]] / [[York Regional Road 7|Highway 7]], west of [[York Regional Road 3|Kennedy Road]] / [[Main Street Unionville]], east of [[York Regional Road 65|Warden Avenue]], and north of [[Ontario Highway 407|Highway 407 ETR]].
On the other hand, Markham Centre or Unionville refers to a broader area. Markham Centre is bounded north to Apple Creek Boulevard / [[Carlton Road]], east to [[York Regional Road 3|Kennedy Road]], west to Rodick Road, and south to [[York Regional Road 71|14th Avenue]].
==History== [[File:Down town markham 17.41.41.jpg|thumb|right|Verclaire Gate South in May 2016.]] [[File:Down town markham 17.39.26.jpg|thumb|right|The Cineplex new theatre just built.]] [[File:DowntownMarkhamConstruction.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Downtown Markham construction site in 2009.]] The current City of Markham was created in 1971 when the former town was expanded by amalgamation with [[Thornhill, Ontario|Thornhill]] and [[Unionville, Ontario|Unionville]]. With its original historic downtown, [[Markham Village, Ontario|Markham Village]], being small and situated tn the far eastern part of the amalgamated municipality, the city decided a larger, more centrally-located downtown was needed.
The area south of Unionville to the east of Warden Avenue was frozen for development by the province during the planning and construction of express toll road Highway 407. In 1992, a plan was approved to develop the area with higher commercial density.
The Town of Markham has approved the plan, according to Markham's former mayor, [[Donald Cousens]].<ref name=GCL /> The community situated in Unionville was planned to be self-sustained and [[Transit-oriented development|transit-oriented]] based on [[smart growth]] development. Construction began in 2005, when [[Enterprise Drive]] was completed.
[[Aviva Canada]] built its second Canadian headquarters on Birchmount Road and a new [[Cineplex Entertainment|Cineplex]] theatre opened on April 4, 2015. It provides a bigger space to include a few VIP theatres, a new gaming corner and much higher capacity than the old Cineplex theatre at [[First Markham Place]].
The [[Marriott International|Marriott]] hotel and the York condo is now under construction on the corner of Enterprise Drive and Birchmount Road. It is scheduled to be finished by the end of 2018.
==Development== Downtown Markham located in the City of Markham's Unionville Village is using a development strategy named [[smart growth]]. The community will try to limit urban sprawl by creating a denser urban centre. The urban centre is planned to be a transit-oriented community, with everything close by and fully transit dependent.<ref name=TheStar /> In addition, the community was also planned to be environmentally sustainable as well.
The community was planned by the City of Markham, in co-operation with The Remington Group. The Remington Group is mainly in charge of constructing most of the structures across this new community.
According to the plan approved by the city council, the community will contain residential condos and townhouses, commercial, and retail buildings.<ref name=GCL /> Some of these structures have already begun construction. Updates as to what is built is underway.
Downtown Markham in Unionville has been nominated as the country's largest mixed-used development, as well as North America's largest LEED (leadership-in-energy-and-environmental-design) registered development.<ref name=100k>{{cite web|url=http://www.downtownmarkham.ca/pdfs/100K%20ClubFINAL_FINAL_Feb28,2008.pdf|title=New York. Paris. London. Toronto?|author=100 Thousand Club|accessdate=2008-06-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706175827/http://www.downtownmarkham.ca/pdfs/100K%20ClubFINAL_FINAL_Feb28%2C2008.pdf|archivedate=2011-07-06|df=}}</ref>
==Transportation== [[File:WardenVIVA3.JPG|thumb|right|250px|[[VivaNext#Completed rapidway stations|Warden Vivastation]]]] The primary modes of transportation in Downtown Markham are: [[List of York Regional Roads|Regional Roads]], [[List of municipal roads in Markham, Ontario|municipal roads]], [[Ontario Highway 407|a toll highway]], [[Viva (bus rapid transit)|bus rapid transit]], and [[GO Transit|GO Trains]].<ref name=TheStar />
===York Regional Roads=== The community is bounded with three York Regional Roads, which are numbered as [[York Regional Road 3|3]] (Kennedy Road), [[York Regional Road 7|7]] (Highway 7), and [[York Regional Road 65|65]] (Warden Avenue).
===Toll Highway=== [[Ontario Highway 407|Highway 407]] serves the community with exits on Warden Avenue and Kennedy Road. The highway leads east to [[Pickering, Ontario|Pickering]] and west to [[Burlington, Ontario|Burlington]].
===Bus Rapid Transit=== The community is served by the [[VivaNext#Completed rapidway stations|Warden]], Enterprise and [[Unionville GO Station|Unionville]] stops on the [[Viva (bus rapid transit)|VIVA]] bus rapid transit system. Warden and Enterprise are served by three lines: [[Viva Purple]], [[Viva Green]], and [[Viva Pink]], while Unionville Station is only served by Viva Pink. As of 2011, [[Viva Purple]] is the only line with all-day service, the other lines operate only during rush hour. It is scheduled that when Downtown Markham is fully functional and occupied, [[Viva Green]] will return to full service. The community is anticipated to be highly dependent on these transit routes, as part of the planned smart growth.
Viva Purple connects the locale to [[Cornell, Ontario|Cornell]] and [[York University]]; Viva Green connects the locale to [[Don Mills (TTC)|Don Mills Station]] and [[Cornell, Ontario|Cornell]]; Viva Pink connects the locale to [[North York, Ontario|North York City Centre]].
Other bus routes that serve the area include: * TTC 68 Warden * YRT 8 Kennedy * YRT 1 Highway 7
===GO Transit=== [[GO Transit]] operates [[Unionville GO Station]] on the [[Stouffville line]] during peak commuter traffic. The GO train line connects the Downtown Markham to [[Whitchurch-Stouffville|Stouffville]] and [[Toronto|Downtown Toronto]].
==Environmental sustainability== The community reserves {{convert|72|acre|m2}} as a natural reserve, which includes an ecologically sensitive area, [[Rouge River (Ontario)|Rouge River]].
==Facilities==
There are two recreational facilities in Downtown Markham:
* [[Markham Pan Am Centre]] was built for [[2015 Pan American Games]] and became a city-owned facility after completion of the games in September 2015 * [[Markham YMCA Rudy Bratty Centre]] was completed in 2006 and upgraded in 2008; featuring two pools and other fitness facilities for YMCA members
==Education==
[[York University]]/[[Seneca College]] [[Markham Campus (York University)|Markham Campus]] site will be built next to the Markham Pan Am Centre.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.markham.ca/wps/portal/Markham/BusinessDevelopment/MarkhamCentre/TheMarkhamCentreStory The Markham Centre Story]

revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=October 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = Fusion GPS | foundation = 2011 | logo = Fusion GPS logo.png | location = Washington, D.C. | key_people = [[Glenn R. Simpson]] | industry = | owner = | num_employees = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.fusiongps.com/}} }}
'''Fusion GPS''' is a commercial research and strategic intelligence firm based in Washington, D.C. The company conducts open-source investigations and provides research and strategic advice for businesses, law firms and investors, as well as for political inquiries, such as [[opposition research]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Fusion GPS – Investigative reporting approach to investment research |url=http://www.integrity-research.com/fusion-gps-investivative-reporting-approach-to-investment-research/|website=Integrity Research|access-date=January 17, 2017|date=April 7, 2011}}</ref> The "GPS" initialism is derived from "Global research, Political analysis, Strategic insight".<ref name=GPS>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110714001553/http://www.fusiongps.com/about.html "About Fusion", archived version of Fusion GPS web site from July 2011]</ref>
==History== The company was co-founded in 2011 by [[Glenn R. Simpson]], a former investigative reporter and journalist for ''[[Roll Call]]'' and ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''; Peter Fritsch, former ''Wall Street Journal'' senior editor; and former ''Wall Street Journal'' journalist Thomas Catan.<ref name="McB">{{cite web|last1=McBride|first1=Jessica|title=Fusion GPS: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know|url=http://heavy.com/news/2017/07/fusion-gps-dossier-russia-trump-jr-christopher-steele-democrat-planned-parenthood-glenn-simpson-peter-fritsch-natalia-veselnitskaya-grassley-hearing/|website=Heavy.com|accessdate=July 22, 2016|date=March 30, 2017}}</ref>
==Work== ===Opposition research on Mitt Romney=== Fusion GPS was hired by [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] in 2012 to do opposition research on U.S. presidential candidate [[Mitt Romney]].<ref name="McB"/> In February 2012, the magazine ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' published an article on [[Frank L. VanderSloot|Frank VanderSloot]] and his company Melaleuca, who combined had given $1 million to a super PAC supporting Mitt Romney. After the article was published, an intern at Fusion GPS did a search of Idaho court records on VanderSloot by phone and fax. In January 2013, VanderSloot sued ''Mother Jones'' for defamation in the February 2012 article. In the course of the litigation, VanderSloot deposed Fusion GPS founder Simpson on the "theory that Mother Jones conspired with Obama's team to defame VanderSloot".<ref name="MoJo">{{cite web|last1=Jeffery|first1=Clara|last2=Bauerlein|first2=Monika|title=We Were Sued by a Billionaire Political Donor. We won. Here's What Happened|url=https://www.motherjones.com/media/2015/10/mother-jones-vandersloot-melaleuca-lawsuit/|website=Mother Jones|accessdate=July 23, 2016|date=October 8, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Motion to Squash Subpoena|url=https://dcslapplaw.com/files/2016/06/Simpson-SLAPP-MOL.pdf|website=D.C. Anti-SLAPP Law|format=PDF|accessdate=July 23, 2016}}</ref><ref name="WSJ">{{cite news|last1=Strassel|first1=Kim|title=Strassel: Trolling for Dirt on the President's List|url=http://www.frankvanderslootresponse.com/wall-street-journal.html|website=FrankVanderslootResponse|accessdate=July 23, 2016|date=May 10, 2012}}</ref> The seventh Judicial District Court of the State of Idaho dismissed the lawsuit in 2015.<ref name="Outcome">{{cite web|title=Case Analysis|url=https://globalfreedomofexpression.columbia.edu/cases/vandersloot-v-mother-jones/|website=Global Freedom of Expression |publisher=Columbia University|accessdate=July 23, 2016|date=October 6, 2015}} Case Number CV-2013-532.</ref>
===Planned Parenthood=== In August 2015, [[Planned Parenthood]] retained Fusion GPS to defensively investigate the veracity of a series of undercover videos released by [[anti-abortion]] activists [[David Daleiden]] and Sandra Merritt from [[The Center for Medical Progress]] that they claim showed Planned Parenthood officials agreeing to sell fetal tissues obtained through abortions to medical researchers. Fusion GPS hired video and transcription experts to analyze the videos and summarized the findings in a forensic report.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hemingway|first1=Mark|title=Politico & NYT Fail to Mention Report Exonerating Planned Parenthood Produced By Democratic Opposition Research Firm|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/politico-nyt-fail-to-mention-report-exonerating-planned-parenthood-produced-by-democratic-opposition-research-firm/article/1020250|website=Weekly Standard|accessdate=17 January 2017|date=27 August 2015}}</ref> The report claimed that the "unedited" videos posted by activists had been "heavily edited". The anti-abortion activists attributed the gaps to "bathroom breaks and waiting periods."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Haberkorn|first1=Jennifer|title=Report for Planned Parenthood finds sting videos manipulated|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/08/planned-parenthood-undercover-videos-report-finds-manipulation-121800|website=Politico.com|accessdate=17 January 2017|date=27 August 2015}}</ref> The report was provided to U.S. congressional leadership as evidence as they were considering funding and other issues related to Planned Parenthood operations.<ref name="MattH">{{Cite web|last=Hamilton|first=Matt | url = http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-planned-parenthood-charges-activists-20170328-story.html | title = Two Antiabortion Activists behind Undercover Planned Parenthood Videos Charged with 15 Felonies | publisher = Los Angeles Times|date=March 28, 2017|accessdate=July 23, 2017}}</ref>
After a grand jury declined to indict Planned Parenthood of any wrongdoing, on March 28, 2017, Daleiden and Merritt were charged with 15 felonies in the State of California - one for each of the people whom they had filmed without consent, and one for criminal conspiracy to invade privacy.<ref name="MattH"/> On 21 June 2017, fourteen of these charges were dismissed, with [[Motion for leave|leave]] to amend, on the grounds that they were legally insufficient.<ref>{{cite news |title=SF judge deals setback to prosecutors in abortion sting videos |author=Bob Egelko |date= June 21, 2017 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/SF-judge-deals-setback-to-prosecutors-in-abortion-11237776.php |accessdate=July 12, 2017}}</ref> On June 30, 2017, state prosecutors refiled the 14 dismissed charges with numerical identifications for each video.<ref>{{cite web|last=Egelko|first=Bob|url=http://m.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/California-files-more-charges-against-11271723.php|title=California files more charges against antiabortion activists |website=SfGate|date=July 7, 2017 | access-date=October 10, 2017 |quote=}}</ref><ref name="BCN">{{cite web |last=News|first=Bay City|url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/sf-court-ruling-allows-felony-charges-proceed-anti-abortion-activists/ |title=SF court ruling allows felony charges to proceed against anti-abortion activists|publisher=Daily Herald|date=August 24, 2017 | access-date=October 10, 2017 |quote=}}</ref> On August 24, 2017, the San Francisco Superior Court rejected new defense motions to dismiss the charges and allowed the case to proceed. Daleiden then pleaded not guilty, while Merritt did not enter a plea at the time.<ref name="BCN"/>
===Prevezon Holding=== In 2013, the US Department of Justice, represented by the US Attorney for the Southern District of New York, [[Preet Bharara]], sued Prevezon Holding, a [[Republic of Cyprus]] corporation registered in New York State as a foreign business corporation, under the [[Magnitsky Act]] for [[money-laundering]]. The lawsuit sought forfeiture of various assets and real estate holdings in the US.<ref name="MacKra">{{Cite web |last1=MacFarquhar|first1=Neil|last2=Kramer|first2=Andrew E.|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/11/world/europe/natalia-veselnitskaya-donald-trump-jr-russian-lawyer.html| title =Natalia Veselnitskaya, Lawyer Who Met Trump Jr., Seen as Fearsome Moscow Insider|publisher = The New York Times|date=July 11, 2017|accessdate=July 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Erb">{{cite web|last1=Erb|first1=Kelly Phillips|title=Lawyer With Key Evidence In Russian Corruption Scandals Falls From Building Before Testifying|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kellyphillipserb/2017/03/24/lawyer-with-key-evidence-in-russian-corruption-scandals-falls-from-building-before-testifying/#702e1b3d526c|website=Forbes|accessdate=July 22, 2017|date=March 24, 2017}}</ref> In May 2017, two months after President Trump had dismissed Bharara, the lawsuit was settled for $6 million, without Prevezon admitting to any wrongdoing and with both sides claiming victory.<ref name="MacKra"/><ref name="settled">{{cite web|last1=Feeley|first1=Jef|last2=Van Voris|first2=Bob|title=Laundering Suit Ends as Russian Firm, U.S. Claim Victory|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-05-13/u-s-reaches-5-9-million-deal-in-russian-fraud-laundering-case|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=July 22, 2016|date=May 13, 2017}}</ref>
The sole shareholder of Prevezon was Russian citizen [[Denis Katsyv]], whose father is Petr Katsyv, vice president of Russia's state-run rail monopoly and "reportedly a business associate of [[Vladimir Yakunin]], a confidant of [[Vladimir Putin]]".<ref name="Erb"/><ref name="rollstone">{{cite web|author1=Matt Taibbi|authorlink1=Matt Taibbi|title=Russiagate and the Magnitsky Affair, Linked Again|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/trump-russia-russiagate-magnitsky-affair-linked-again-w492290|website=Rolling Stone|accessdate=7 August 2017|date=14 July 2017}}</ref> Katsyv’s Russian lawyer [[Natalia Veselnitskaya]] was not licensed to practice in the US, and Katsyv hired the law firm of [[BakerHostetler]] to represent Prevezon; BakerHostetler hired Fusion GPS in early 2014 to provide research help for the litigation.<ref name=frankel /><ref name=RFE /><ref name="rollstone"/><ref name="rfe2016">{{cite web|last1=Eckel|first1=Mike|title=In U.S. Money-Laundering Case, Shades Of Russian Corruption|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/us-money-laundering-case-russian-corruption-browder-magnitsky-prevezon-katsyv/27494612.html|website=RadioFreeEurope|accessdate=7 August 2017|date=18 January 2016}}</ref>
On October 18, 2016, the appellate court disqualified BakerHostetler from the case because they had represented [[Bill Browder]]’s hedge fund [[Hermitage Capital Management]] for nine months in 2008/2009 when the U.S. Justice Department was investigating a tax fraud scheme in Russia involving "co-opted Hermitage portfolio companies". The U.S. Justice Department had argued that Hermitage Capital was a victim of the tax fraud and that BakerHofstetler’s prior work on behalf of Hermitage Capital created a conflict of interest.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dilanian|first=Ken|title=The Legal Battle Behind the Trump Tower Meeting|url= http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/legal-battle-behind-trump-tower-meeting-n785776|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=August 12, 2017|date=July 24, 2017}}</ref><ref name="frankel">{{cite web|last=Frankel|first=Alison|title=2nd Circuit disqualifies BakerHostetler from forfeiture case in rare mandamus grant|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/alison-frankel/2016/10/18/2nd-circuit-disqualifies-bakerhostetler-from-forfeiture-case-in-rare-mandamus-grant|publisher=Reuters Blog|accessdate=August 12, 2017|date=October 18, 2016}}</ref> As part of their litigation support for BakerHostetler and their client Verezon, Fusion GPS investigated Browder, a witness central to the U.S. Justice Department's case.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Matthews|first1=Christopher M.| url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/hedge-fund-managers-credibility-questioned-in-russian-laundering-case-1431557601 | title = Hedge-Fund Manager's Credibility Questioned in Russian Laundering Case | publisher = The Wall Street Journal|date=May 13, 2015}}</ref>
On July 27, 2017, Fusion GPS accused the White House of trying to "smear" it for investigating the president's alleged ties to Russia. White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders pointed to Browder's testimony as vindication of Trump's claims that ongoing investigations into potential ties between his campaign and Moscow are political ploys to undermine his presidency. Fusion GPS countered that it worked only with a law firm in New York "to provide support for civil litigation" unrelated to Russian efforts to do away with the Magnitsky Act, saying it had no reason to register under the [[Foreign Agents Registration Act]] (FARA).<ref name = TH-Greenwood/>
Browder lodged a complaint with the U.S. Justice Department in 2016 that Fusion GPS may have lobbied "for Russian interests in a campaign to oppose the pending Global Magnitsky Act [and] failed to register under [U.S. law]".<ref name="RFE">{{cite web|last1=Eckel|first1=Mike|title=U.S. Senator Seeks Probe Of Firm Linked To Russia Dossier|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/us-senator-magnitsky-russia-dossier-investigation/28404229.html|website=RadioFreeEurope|date=April 1, 2017|accessdate=July 23, 2017}}</ref><ref name="FARA">{{cite web|last1=Arnsdorf|first1=Isaac|url = http://www.politico.com/tipsheets/politico-influence/2016/12/fara-complaint-alleges-pro-russian-lobbying-217776 | title = FARA Complaint Alleges Pro-Russian Lobbying|publisher = Politico|accessdate=July 23, 2017|date=December 16, 2016}}</ref> The Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act (not to be confused with the Magnitsky Act) is a human rights law passed on December 23, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=The US Global Magnitsky Act: Questions and Answers|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/09/13/us-global-magnitsky-act|website=www.hrw.org|publisher=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=26 December 2017|language=en|date=13 September 2017}}</ref> It is also named after [[Sergei Magnitsky]], a lawyer and auditor working for Browder who died in a Russian prison after uncovering a corruption scheme that he was then charged with having helped concoct.<ref name="rollstone" />
On March 30, 2017, [[Charles Grassley|Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa]] called for a U.S. Department of Justice investigation into purported connections between Fusion GPS and Russia, and an inquiry as to whether Fusion GPS was acting as an unregistered foreign agent. The company denied the claims that they were engaged in lobbying or had violated the Foreign Agents Registration Act.<ref name=FARA/><ref name="RFE"/> According to the ''Washington Post''′s "Fact Checker" column, there is "no evidence that the Russian government paid for Fusion’s work on the Prevezon defense at the same time Fusion investigated Trump’s business dealings in Russia."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2017/08/09/trump-russia-and-the-opposition-research-firm-run-by-ex-journalists/|title=Trump, Russia and the opposition research firm run by ex-journalists|last=Kessler|first=Glenn|date=August 9, 2017|work=Washington Post|accessdate=27 October 2017}}</ref>
===Trump dossier and Christopher Steele=== {{main|Trump–Russia dossier}} In September 2015, Fusion GPS was hired by ''[[The Washington Free Beacon]]'', a conservative political website, to do opposition research on Trump and other Republican presidential candidates. In spring 2016 when Trump had emerged as the probable Republican candidate, the ''Free Beacon'' stopped funding investigation into Trump.<ref name = "freebeacon" /> From April 2016 through October 2016, the law firm [[Perkins Coie]], on behalf of the Clinton campaign and the [[Democratic National Committee]], retained Fusion GPS to continue opposition research on Trump.<ref name = "how">{{cite web|last1=Confessore|first1=Scott Shane, Nicholas|last2=Rosenberg|first2=Matthew|title=How a Sensational, Unverified Dossier Became a Crisis for Donald Trump|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/11/us/politics/donald-trump-russia-intelligence.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=17 January 2017|date=11 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="clintondnclawyer">{{Cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/clinton-campaign-dnc-paid-for-research-that-led-to-russia-dossier/2017/10/24/226fabf0-b8e4-11e7-a908-a3470754bbb9_story.html |title=Clinton campaign, DNC paid for research that led to Russia dossier |last=Entous |first=Adam |last2=Barrett |first2=Devlin |date=October 24, 2017 |website=The Washington Post |language=en-US |access-date=October 25, 2017 |last3=Helderman |first3=Rosalind S.}}</ref><ref name="hrcdossier" /> In June 2016, Fusion GPS retained [[Christopher Steele]], a private British corporate intelligence investigator and former [[MI-6]] agent, to research any Russian connections to Trump. Steele produced a 35-page series of memos from June to December 2016, which became the document known as the [[Donald Trump–Russia dossier]].<ref name = "how" /><ref name="VFBlum">{{cite web|last1=Blum|first1=Howard|title=How ex-spy Christopher Steele compiled his explosive dossier|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/03/how-the-explosive-russian-dossier-was-compiled-christopher-steele|website=Vanity Fair|accessdate=July 22, 2016|date=March 30, 2017}}</ref> Fusion GPS provided [[Marc Elias]], the lead election lawyer for Perkins Coie, with the resulting dossier and other research documents.<ref name="clintondnclawyer" /><ref name="hrcdossier">{{cite web|last1=Vogel|first1=Kenneth P.|title=Clinton Campaign and Democratic Party Helped Pay for Russia Trump Dossier|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/24/us/politics/clinton-dnc-russia-dossier.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=28 October 2017|date=24 October 2017}}</ref>
The firm is being sued for defamation by three [[Alfa-Bank]] owners named in the dossier as connected to Putin. [[German Khan]], one of the litigants and one of Russia's wealthiest citizens, is the father-in-law of [[Alex van der Zwaan]], who was charged in the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|Mueller probe]] for making false statements to the FBI.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Hsu |first1=Spencer S. |last2=Helderman |first2=Rosalind S. |date=20 February 2018 |title=In Mueller probe, son-in-law of Russian businessman pleads guilty to false statements |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/mueller-probe-london-based-son-of-russian-businessman-to-plead-guilty-to-false-statements/2018/02/20/142f4d2e-164b-11e8-b681-2d4d462a1921_story.html |work=The Washington Post |access-date=11 July 2018}}</ref> He pleaded guilty to one count and in April 2018 was sentenced to 30 days in prison and a fine of $20,000.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/04/03/lawyer-connected-russia-election-interference-investigation-receives-30-day-sentence/481359002/ |title=Lawyer connected to Russia election interference investigation receives 30-day sentence |last=Johnson |first=Kevin |date=April 3, 2018 |work=USA TODAY |access-date=April 4, 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/03/us/alex-van-der-zwaan-sentencing-russia-investigation-mueller.html |title=Ex-Skadden Lawyer Is Sentenced to 30 Days in Russia Inquiry |last=LaFraniere |first=Sharon |date=April 3, 2018 |work=The New York Times |access-date=April 4, 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
====House Intelligence Committee investigation==== On October 4, 2017, Chairman [[Devin Nunes]] of the House Intelligence Committee issued subpoenas to the management of the company, demanding documents and testimony in late October and early November 2017. According to a Democratic committee source, the subpoenas were issued unilaterally by the Republican majority of the committee.<ref name="Nunes_subpoena">{{cite web |last1=Perez|first1=Evan|last2=Raju|first2=Manu|last3=Herb|first3=Jeremy|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/10/10/politics/fusion-gps-subpoenas-devin-nunes/index.html|title=Nunes signs off on new subpoenas to firm behind Trump–Russia dossier|publisher=CNN|date=October 11, 2017 | access-date=October 14, 2017}}</ref> {{Wikisource|House Intelligence Committee Interview of Glenn Simpson}} On October 18, 2017, the House Intelligence Committee held a private meeting with two executives of Fusion GPS, Peter Fritsch, and Thomas Catan. The purpose was to seek information about their creation of "the opposition-research dossier that makes salacious claims about President Donald Trump’s ties to Russia."<ref name=Bloomberg-House>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-18/executives-of-firm-tied-to-trump-dossier-won-t-answer-queries|title=Executives of Firm Tied to Trump Dossier Take the Fifth at Committee Meeting|last=House|first=Billy|date=October 18, 2017}}</ref> The meeting was attended by committee staff and a single committee member, Representative [[Tom Rooney (Florida politician)|Tom Rooney]] (R-FL). In response to the questions asked at the meeting, Fritsch and Catan invoked their [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment rights]] against self-incrimination. Their attorney, Joshua Levy, said that prior to the meeting he had informed the committee in writing that his clients would invoke their rights, but they were compelled to appear nevertheless. He added they would cooperate with "serious" investigations but that a "Trump cabal has carried out a campaign to demonize our client for having been tied to the Trump dossier."<ref name=Bloomberg-House/><ref name="subpoena2">{{cite web|last=Green|first=Miranda|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/10/21/politics/fusion-gps-injunction/index.html|title=Fusion GPS asks court to stop lawmakers from seeing financial records|publisher=CNN|date=October 22, 2017|access-date=October 25, 2017}}</ref>
On October 23, 2017, Fusion GPS filed for a court injunction against Nunes' subpoena seeking the firm's bank records for a period of more than two years, arguing it would damage and possibly destroy the business as well as violate their First Amendment rights.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bertrand|first=Natasha|title=The firm behind the Trump–Russia dossier is fighting to shield its bank records from Devin Nunes|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/fusion-gps-trump-russia-subpoena-bank-records-2017-10|work=Business Insider|access-date=October 25, 2017|date=October 24, 2017}}</ref> On January 4, 2018 U.S. District Court Judge [[Richard J. Leon]] struck down Fusion's application, ruling that Fusion's bank must turn over the financial records subpoenaed by the House Intelligence Committee; Fusion asked the judge to stay his order because they plan to appeal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2018/01/04/politics/fusion-gps-bank-records-house-investigation/index.html|title=Fusion GPS fighting order to turn over bank records|last=Polantz|first=Katelyn|date=January 5, 2018|publisher=CNN|accessdate=5 January 2018}}</ref>
On October 28, 2017, ''[[The Washington Free Beacon]]'', a conservative political website, told the House Intelligence Committee that it had retained Fusion GPS's services from 2015 to May 2016, to research Donald Trump and other Republican presidential candidates. The objective was the discovery of damaging information. The ''Free Beacon'' and its primary source of funding, hedge fund manager [[Paul Singer (businessman)|Paul Singer]], denied any involvement in the creation of the Steele dossier, pointing out that they had stopped funding research on Trump before Steele was engaged.<ref name="freebeacon">{{cite news|last1=Vogel|first1=Kenneth P.|last2=Haberman|first2=Maggie|title=Conservative Website First Funded Anti-Trump Research by Firm That Later Produced Dossier|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/27/us/politics/trump-dossier-paul-singer.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=November 1, 2017|date=October 27, 2017}}</ref>
On January 2, 2018, the founders of Fusion GPS, [[Glenn R. Simpson]] and Peter Fritsch, authored an op-ed in ''[[The New York Times]]'', requesting that Republicans "release full transcripts of our firm’s testimony" and further explaining that, "the Steele dossier was not the trigger for the F.B.I.’s investigation into Russian meddling. As we told the Senate Judiciary Committee in August, our sources said the dossier was taken so seriously because it corroborated reports the bureau had received from other sources, including one inside the Trump camp."<ref name = oped>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/02/opinion/republicans-investigation-fusion-gps.html|title=Opinion {{!}} The Republicans’ Fake Investigations|last=Simpson|first=Glenn R.|date=2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-03|last2=Fritsch|first2=Peter|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
The committee interviewed Simpson for seven hours on November 14, 2017. The transcript of the interview was released on January 18, 2018.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dukakis|first1=Ali|last2=Madden|first2=Pete|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/house-intel-committee-released-transcript-interview-fusion-gps/story?id=52443886 |title=House Intel committee has released a transcript from their interview with Fusion GPS co-founder Glenn Simpson|publisher=ABC News|date=January 18, 2018|access-date=January 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Tucker|first=Eric|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/house-releases-transcript-of-interview-tied-to-trump-dossier/2018/01/18/4929e37a-fc99-11e7-9b5d-bbf0da31214d_story.html|title=Transcript: Trump dossier first focused on real estate deals|website=The Washington Post|date=January 18, 2018|access-date=January 18, 2018}}</ref>
==Senate Judiciary Committee investigations== {{Wikisource|Senate Judiciary Committee Interview of Glenn Simpson}}
Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Grassley and ranking Democrat [[Dianne Feinstein]] made arrangements in July 2017 for Fusion GPS co-founder Glenn Simpson to testify before their committee. It was agreed that Simpson would not testify in public but would be interviewed privately.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2017-07-25/the-latest-trump-mocks-hill-probe-on-russia|title=The Latest: Senate Panel Subpoenas Manafort to Testify|date=July 25, 2017|work=U.S. News and World Report|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref><ref name="Greenwood_7/26/2017">{{cite web | last=Greenwood | first=Max | title=Co-founder of firm tied to Trump dossier agrees to speak to Senate panel | website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | date=July 26, 2017 | url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/343697-co-founder-of-firm-tied-to-trump-dossier-agrees-to-speak-to-senate | access-date=July 28, 2017}}</ref> The committee wanted to question Simpson about the [[Foreign Agents Registration Act]] (FARA). A previous witness, banker and human rights activist Bill Browder, had accused Simpson and Fusion GPS of evading registration as foreign agents for campaigning to influence and overturn the [[Magnitsky Act]].<ref name=TH-Greenwood>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/news/344207-fusion-gps-white-house-trying-to-smear-us-on-russia | title=Fusion GPS: White House Trying To Smear Us On Russia |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |last=Greenwood|first=Max|first2= Megan|last2=Wilson|date=July 27, 2017|accessdate=August 1, 2017}}</ref> Fusion GPS said through their attorney that they were not required to register under FARA.<ref name=TH-Greenwood/> Senators were expected to also use the hearing "to press Justice Department officials on what they know about Veselnitskaya, Prevezon, Fusion GPS and their connections to both the Trump campaign or the Russian government."<ref name="BI-July">{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/fusion-gps-trump-dossier-russia-trump-jr-manafort-2017-7|title=Senate Intel Committee Subpoenas The Research Firm Tied To The Bombshell Trump–Russia Dossier|work=[[Business Insider]]|last=Logan|first=Bryan|date=July 21, 2017|accessdate=July 24, 2017}}</ref>
On August 22, 2017, Simpson was questioned for 10 hours by the Senate Judiciary Committee in a closed-door meeting. The Committee did not release a transcript of the hearing, but indicated that Fusion GPS had given more than 40,000 documents for the investigation.<ref name="DukMo">{{cite news|last1=Dukakis|first1=Ali|last2=Mosk|first2=Matthew|title=Attorney: Glenn Simpson did not reveal clients for Trump 'dossier' to investigators|url= http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/attorney-glenn-simpson-reveal-clients-trump-dossier-investigators/story?id=49367909|work=ABC News|date=August 22, 2017|access-date= August 25, 2017}}</ref> Simpson kept the identities of the firm’s clients confidential;<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/22/congress-investigate-fusion-gps-simpson-241924|title=Fusion GPS co-founder meets with congressional investigators|date=August 22, 2017|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Politico|accessdate=27 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/08/22/trump-dossier-figure-questioned-behind-closed-doors-on-capitol-hill.html|title=Trump dossier figure questioned behind closed doors on Capitol Hill|last=Singman|first=Brooke|date=August 22, 2017|work=Fox News|accessdate=27 October 2017}}</ref> the client names—conservative website ''[[The Washington Free Beacon]]'',<ref name="freebeacon" /> and a law firm representing the DNC and the Clinton presidential campaign<ref name="clintondnclawyer" />—were revealed in October 2017 as a result of the House Intelligence Committee investigation.
On January 2, 2018, Simpson and Fritsch co-authored an op-ed in ''The New York Times'', requesting the two congressional committees to "release full transcripts of our firm's testimony".<ref name = oped/> On January 8, 2018, a spokesman for Grassley said he did not plan to release the transcript of Simpson's August 22, 2017, testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-08/grassley-won-t-release-fusion-gps-transcript-from-russia-probe|title=Grassley Won't Release Fusion GPS Transcript From Russia Probe|last=Dennis|first=Steven T.|date=January 8, 2017|work=Bloomberg News|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref> The next day, January 9, 2018, Feinstein unilaterally released the transcript.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Barrett|first1=Devlin|last2=Hamburger|first2=Tom|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/feinstein-releases-testimony-of-glenn-simpson-whose-research-firm-fusion-gps-was-behind-trump-dossier/2018/01/09/15da150a-f562-11e7-beb6-c8d48830c54d_story.html|title=Feud over Trump dossier intensifies with release of interview transcript|website=The Washington Post|date=January 10, 2017|access-date=January 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Fandos|first1=Nicholas|last2=Rosenberg|first2=Matthew|last3=LaFraniere|first3=Sharon|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/09/us/politics/feinstein-fusion-gps-glenn-simpson-transcript.html|title=Democratic Senator Releases Transcript of Interview with Dossier Firm|website=The New York Times|date=January 9, 2017|access-date=January 9, 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[2016 Democratic National Committee email leak]] * [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox fashion designer |image = Haute Couture Spring-Summer 2011 (5550091258).jpg |caption = |name = Georges Hobeika |birth_name = Georges J. Hobeika |nationality = [[Lebanese nationality law|Lebanese]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1962|2|8}} |birth_place = [[Baskinta]], Lebanon |education = |label_name = Georges Hobeika, GH |significant_design = |occupation = [[Fashion Designer]] |awards = |website = {{URL|www.georgeshobeika.com}} |social = {{URL|instagram.com/georgeshobeika}} |}} '''Georges Hobeika''' ([[Baskinta]], 8 February 1962) is a [[Lebanese people|Lebanese]] [[fashion designer]] of [[haute couture]] and [[ready-to-wear]] clothing. Hobeika officially opened his atelier in [[Beirut]], [[Lebanon]] in 1995, and has been presenting his collections in [[Paris]], during the city’s official [[Paris Fashion Week|fashion weeks]], for over a decade. Hobeika is officially recognized by the "[[List of grands couturiers|Chambre Syndicale de la Haute Couture]]", as a guest member.<ref>http://www.fashionwindows.net/2009/11/georges-hobeika/</ref>
Today, Hobeika owns and manages his fashion house which includes four lines: Georges Hobeika Couture – Georges Hobeika Bridal – Georges Hobeika Signature – GH by Georges Hobeika. Georges Hobeika operates the fashion label from his showroom on the [[rue Royale]] in Paris and from his atelier headquarters in Beirut.<ref>http://uk.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/1037404/interview-georges-hobeikas-new-couture</ref>
==Early years==
Hobeika was born in [[Baskinta]], a village in the mountains of Lebanon, and was one of eight siblings. His mother, Marie, was a seamstress and encouraged her children to assist her in her boutique atelier. Hobeika particularly liked his mother’s vocation and pursued it as a passionate hobby.<ref>http://www.ultraextra.org/interviews/2012/12/7/9vrjaj3ds463h1bnk8435uzsnmmpqt</ref>
Hobeika studied civil engineering in university, and pursued architectural design in his studies. The [[Lebanese Civil War]] forced him to leave the country in order to secure a better future for him and his family. Hobeika traveled to Paris and worked as an intern for several Parisian fashion houses, including [[Chanel]].<ref>http://jetsetfashionmagazine.com/wordpress/fashion/my-interview-with-georges-hobeika</ref>
== The Georges Hobeika Design Label == After returning from Paris, Georges Hobeika opened his first atelier location in Beirut, Lebanon in 1995. Around this time, his mother closed her atelier and referred all of her clients to him. They worked together to establish a fashion label.<ref>http://www.modemonline.com/fashion/mini-web-sites/fashion-brands/references/georgeshobeika</ref>
In 2001, Hobeika had his first show in Paris, at "Hotel K,". Hobeika has shown his couture collections in every biannual [[Paris Fashion Week|Paris Couture Fashion Week]] since.<ref>http://www.poshglam.com/georges-hobeika-a-paris/</ref>
In 2010, Georges Hobeika opened a showroom in Paris. Additionally, Hobeika opened a second production facility dedicated to his Signature and GH by Georges Hobeika lines.<ref>http://uk.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/1037404/interview-georges-hobeikas-new-couture</ref><ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Culture/Lifestyle/2012/Mar-23/167666-georges-hobeika-presents-a-vision-of-classic-femininity.ashx</ref><ref>http://crystals.swarovski.com/magazine/issue17/georges-hobeika.en.php</ref>
Georges Hobeika has diversified into a décor line of couture furnishings and home accessories.<ref>http://jetsetfashionmagazine.com/wordpress/fashion/my-interview-with-georges-hobeika</ref>
The Georges Hobeika brand is currently headed from Beirut and has official PR representation branches in Paris (in-house), [[Los Angeles]] and [[Beijing]].<ref>http://fashionweekdaily.com/the-daily-media-15/</ref> Hobeika has partnered with [[Maison Lesage]], [[Swarovski]], Maison Legeron, Jakob Schlaepfer, and Solstiss for the creation and production of the Georges Hobeika Couture line.<ref>http://couleurblind.me/2010/05/24/only-superficial-people-pay-no-attention-to-surface-appearance/</ref><ref>http://www.pinterest.com/rexfabrics/jakob-schlaepfer/</ref><ref>http://crystals.swarovski.com/magazine/issue17/georges-hobeika.en.php</ref>
== International clientele == Hobeika has designed clothing for royal families in Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Kuwait. He also has clients from Europe, North and South America, and Asia.<ref>http://uk.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/1037404/interview-georges-hobeikas-new-couture</ref>
On 19 December 2012, Georges Hobeika received worldwide recognition when former Miss USA [[Olivia Culpo]] was crowned [[Miss Universe]] 2012. Culpo won the title wearing a Georges Hobeika gown for the final evening gown segment of the competition. It was the first time a couture gown that debuted during a Paris Couture Week was worn for the competition.<ref>http://www.pashionmagazine.com/george-hobeika-dresses-miss-universe/</ref>

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6beta2)
revision.text:
'''Graham Fink''' is a <ref>http://www.campaignasia.com/Article/257237,graham-fink-quits-mc-saatchi-london-for-ogilvy-china.aspx</ref> Multimedia artist and Chief Creative Officer at the advertising agency [[Ogilvy & Mather]] China.
Before taking up that appointment in April 2011 he was <ref>http://www.brandrepublic.com/Campaign/News/488673/M-C-Saatchi-hires-Graham-Fink/?DCMP=ILC-BETAMORE</ref> Executive Creative Director at [[M&C Saatchi]] in London. In 1995, he began directing television commercials and music videos at the Paul Weiland film company. Previously, he was Deputy Creative Director at the Gold Greenlees Trott, and Group Head at Saatchi & Saatchi and WCRS. Before that he was an Art Director at CDP. To get this job he dressed up as an old man ( CDP didn't take on junior creatives ). His first job in advertising was as Art Director at Medcalf, Wrightson, Lovelock. All five companies are or were London advertising agencies.
He became the youngest ever President of [[D&AD]] (Design and Art Directors Association) in 1996.<ref>http://www.dandad.org/inspiration/profiles/individuals/graham-fink</ref> He was subsequently voted into [[D&AD]]'s 'Art Direction book' representing the top 28 Art Directors of all time.<ref>http://www.dandad.org/inspiration/profiles/individuals/graham-fink</ref>
He is one of the worlds most awarded creatives having won awards at Cannes, D&AD, One Show, BAFTA, Clio's, LIAA, BTAA, Campaign's UK Big Awards, Creative Circle, Mobius, Eurobest, EPICA, New York Festival, China 4A's, Longxi, SPIKES. In 2011 he won the UK Creative Circle President's Award. And in 2012 he won Ogilvy Asia's first ever Cannes Grand Prix.
His award-winning photography has been used in many advertising campaigns including [[PlayStation]]'s 'Blood' and 'Mental Wealth' poster campaigns. He also directed a short film ( Z ) for the Millennium, commissioned by [[David Puttnam]] which was shortlisted at [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]].
In 2001 he created <ref>http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-5838960_ITM</ref> thefinktank, a conceptual production company and ideas forum. In 2005 he was awarded a <ref>http://bucks.ac.uk/about/structure/directorates/student_and_academic_services/academic_services/graduation_information/honorary_awards.aspx</ref> Honorary Doctorate at ''[[Bucks New University]]''
In 2014 he had his first one-man exhibition at London's Riflemaker gallery called NOMADS. In 2015 he had his second exhibition in London entitled Drawing with my eyes. For this he drew directly onto a screen using only his eyes via a Tobii eye tracker and software he developed himself with Tobii. http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/24/graham-fink-eyes_n_6932762.html?1427226337
==References== {{reflist}}

{{more citations needed|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox video game |title = Hoyle Casino Empire |image = Hoyle_Casino_Empire_Cover_art.jpg |image_size = 250px |caption = Cover art |developer = [[Sierra Entertainment]] |publisher = Sierra Entertainment |released = {{Video game release|NA|September 23, 2002}} |designer = |engine = |composer = Mike Caviezel |genre = [[Business simulation game]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] }}
'''''Hoyle Casino Empire''''' is a [[business simulation game|business simulation]] developed and published by [[Sierra Entertainment]] on Windows computers, in which the player must run a casino and try to make profit, attract customers and get good ratings.
==Gameplay== The goal of ''Hoyle Casino Empire'' is to create a thriving casino. There are two modes in the game; Empire Mode and Sandbox Mode. Empire Mode sends the player to one of eight casinos starting with a small one and working up to the biggest casino. In each casino the player will have specific objectives to meet in a limited time in order turn the casino into a successful place. Not meeting the objectives in time will end the game. Sandbox mode allows the player to build whatever casino desired without any objectives to follow or limited time. In this mode, the player is limited to one kind of casino, but can unlock more upon winning them from the Empire Mode.
The player starts in a specific kind of building with a limited amount of starting money, certain areas of space to build, and starting at a First Level Status. A Level Status determines what kind of casino games and services can be built in the casino. Increasing a Level Status requires a sum of cash, a number of customers in the casino and a number of good ratings. The Level Status can go as high as four. The number of customers can be increased by introducing more games and services and the good ratings can be increased by introducing variety, room decor, building extensions, cash donations, deluxe services and satisfying customers' general requirements.
General requirements for customers include cash desks (and ATMs) to withdraw money for gambling, bathrooms, eating establishments, drinking establishments and hotel accommodations. If those general requirements are not met, customers may decide to leave the casino and give bad reviews. Cash donations can only keep dissatisfied customers happy temporarily. Customers come in different classes, ranging from Tourists who carry little cash to VIPs who have lots of money. When building games and services in the casino, maintenance is needed to keep the casino running. Service men are needed to maintain the slot machines, custodians keep the casino and bathrooms clean, waitresses serve drinks and security guards keep unwanted offenders out.
Earning money legally is done by establishing sufficient services to the number of customers and accepting commercial stunt deals with agreements met. However money can be earned illegitimately by increasing the House Edge to Cheating Mode, accepting crooked deals such as money laundering. Such illegalities can lead to financial losses and degrading of ratings if found out by city authorities. While attempting to earn profit, the player must keep in mind the maintenance and employee wage expenses that present in the gameplay. If money goes below zero, then the player is in debt and cannot spend on anymore services or building until sufficient cash is earned.
==Reception== {{Video game reviews <!-- Reviewers --> | Allgame = {{rating|3|5}})<ref name="HoyleCE-Allgame">{{cite web|url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=38276|title=Hoyle Casino Empire Review - Allgame|author=Michael L. House|last=|first=|publisher=Allgame|date=|accessdate=June 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141211191559/http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=38276|archive-date=December 11, 2014}}</ref> | GSpot = 5.9/10<ref name="HoyleCE-GSpot">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com:80/pc/strategy/casinoempire/review.html|title=Hoyle Casino Empire - GameSpot|author=Andrew Park|last=|first=|publisher=GameZone|date=October 4, 2002|accessdate=June 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930230411/http://www.gamespot.com/pc/strategy/casinoempire/review.html|archive-date=September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> | GSpy = {{rating|3.5|5}})<ref name="HoyleCE-GSpy">{{cite web|url=http://pc.gamespy.com/pc/casino-empire/582653p1.html|title=Hoyle Casino Empire - GameSpy|author=Kevin Rice|last=|first=|publisher=GameSpy|date=October 30, 2002|accessdate=June 23, 2017}}</ref> | GameZone = 8.4/10<ref name="HoyleCE-GZone">{{cite web|url=http://pc.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r19847.htm|title=Hoyle Casino Empire - GameZone|author=Michael Lafferty|last=|first=|publisher=GameZone|date=September 30, 2002|accessdate=June 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090101070056/http://pc.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r19847.htm|archive-date=January 1, 2009}}</ref> | IGN = 6.2/10<ref name="HoyleCE-IGN">{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/games/casino-empire|title=Hoyle Casino Empire - IGN|last=|first=|publisher=IGN|date=|accessdate=June 23, 2017}}</ref> }} "Hoyle Casino Empire" received a number of mixed reviews.

{{more footnotes|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox Congressman |name =James A. Haley |image =James A. Haley.jpg |birth_date= {{birth date|1899|1|4}} |birth_place =[[Jacksonville, Alabama|Jacksonville]], [[Alabama]] |death_date= {{death date and age|1981|8|6|1899|1|4}} |death_place=[[Sarasota, Florida]] |state1 = [[Florida]] |district1 = [[Florida's 8th congressional district|8th]] |term_start1=January 3, 1973 |term_end1=January 3, 1977 |preceded1 = [[Bill Young]] |succeeded1 = [[Andy Ireland]] |state2 = [[Florida]] |district2 = [[Florida's 7th congressional district|7th]] |term_start2=January 3, 1953 |term_end2=January 3, 1973 |preceded2 = ''district created'' |succeeded2 = [[Sam Gibbons]] |party =[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |profession = Businessman |spouse = Aubrey Barlow Ringling (née Black) }} '''James Andrew Haley''' (January 4, 1899 – August 6, 1981) was a [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] from [[Florida]]. Born in [[Jacksonville, Alabama|Jacksonville]], [[Alabama]], Haley attended the public schools and the [[University of Alabama]]. During World War I, Haley enlisted in Troop A, Second Cavalry, in April 1917 and served overseas. He was an accountant in [[Sarasota, Florida|Sarasota]], Florida, from 1920 to 1933. He served as general manager of John Ringling estate 1933–1943. On December 4, 1942, Haley married Aubrey Ringling (née Aubrey Barlow Black), the widow of Richard T. Ringling who had died in 1931. Richard Ringling was the son of [[Alf T. Ringling]] one of the original [[Ringling brothers]].https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=57843603 From 1943 to 1945, he was the first vice president of Ringling Circus and president and director of [[Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey]]. In 1944, [[Hartford circus fire|a fire broke out at a Ringling Circus show]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut]] that killed 169 persons. On the day of the fire Haley was the highest ranking executive traveling with the circus. http://www.tbo.com/health/medical-news/haley-volunteer-pushing-for-rename-of-hospital-540080 During the subsequent trial, he and five other circus officials pleaded [[Nolo contendere|no contest]] to charges of [[involuntary manslaughter]] and were sentenced to prison. He served eight months{{cite news |title=Ringling V.P. Released After Serving 8 Mos. of Fire Penalty |url=https://archive.org/stream/variety160-1945-12#page/n198/mode/1up/ |accessdate=2017-01-15 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=1945-12-26 |page=39}} and in 1945 was returned to Florida, where he received a [[pardon]] from [[governor of Florida|Governor]] [[Millard F. Caldwell]].http://www.flsouthern.edu/library/mckay-archives/digital-exhibits/haley-congressman.aspx Haley worked for Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey from 1946 to 1948. He later engaged in newspaper publishing and later in general printing business. He served as chairman of the Democratic executive committee of Sarasota County 1935–1952. He served as member of the [[Florida House of Representatives]] from 1949 to 1952. He was a delegate in [[1952 Democratic National Convention|1952]], [[1956 Democratic National Convention|1956]], and [[1960 Democratic National Convention|1960]] to all three [[Democratic National Convention]]s. Haley was elected as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the [[83rd United States Congress|Eighty-third]] and to the eleven succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1953 – January 3, 1977). He served as chairman of the Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs ([[93rd United States Congress|Ninety-third]] and [[94th United States Congress|Ninety-fourth]] Congresses). In the high-profile 1970 election for the [[United States Senate]] from Florida to choose a successor to [[Spessard L. Holland]], Haley strongly supported his fellow Democrat [[Lawton Chiles]], a [[Florida State Senate|state senator]] from [[Lakeland, Florida|Lakeland]], who scored an easy victory over the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Candidate|nominee]], [[William C. Cramer]] of [[St. Petersburg, Florida|St. Petersburg]]. Haley called Cramer "little in stature and big in mouth" and suggested that the Republican candidate should "talk less and work more."Billy Hathorn, "Cramer v. Kirk: The Florida Republican Schism of 1970", ''Florida Historical Quarterly'' (April 1990), p. 413 Haley was not a candidate for reelection to the [[95th United States Congress|Ninety-fifth]] Congress in 1976. Haley died in Sarasota on August 6, 1981 and was interred in Boca Raton Cemetery in [[Boca Raton, Florida|Boca Raton]]. The James A. Haley Veterans Hospital located in [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] is named after him. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Bioguide}} {{CongBio|H000041}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Florida | district=7 | before=''District created'' | after=[[Sam Gibbons]] | years=1953–1973 }} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Florida | district=8 | before=[[Bill Young]] | after=[[Andy Ireland]] | years=1973–1977 }} {{s-off|us}} {{succession box |title=Chairman of [[United States House Committee on Natural Resources|House Interior and Insular Affairs Committee]] |before=[[Wayne N. Aspinall]]
Colorado |years=1973–1977 |after=[[Mo Udall]]
Arizona }} {{s-end}} {{US House Natural Resources chairs}} {{U.S. Florida Representatives}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haley, James Andrew}} [[Category:1899 births]] [[Category:1981 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:20th-century American politicians]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War I]] [[Category:American people convicted of manslaughter]] [[Category:Florida Democrats]] [[Category:Members of the Florida House of Representatives]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Florida]] [[Category:Recipients of American gubernatorial pardons]] [[Category:Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus people]] [[Category:People from Jacksonville, Alabama]] [[Category:People from Sarasota, Florida]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]] [[Category:University of Alabama alumni]] [[Category:Democratic Party members of the United States House of Representatives]]
